You turned around and walked into the kitchen. Light was on and you could easily see Molly. Maybe you couldn't see her face, because it was hidden under her paws, but it still wasn't pleasant view. You stopped next to the chair Molly was sitting on.

"You should close the door" Maybe that wasn't your best idea. You scared her and she jumped, shaking the ground. She probably didn't fell it, but you weren't ready for it and you fell.

Molly crouched, still stunned. She wanted to grab you, but stopped herself few times, not knowing what to do. You think you must help her.

"What are you waiting for?" And you immediately find yourself being cuddled in her cheek fur. You spend half minute in this position, until Molly finally takes you away.

"Why?" Her face isn't the sight you are pleasant to see. Her fur around eyes is wet, with some part under eyes. At least now she's smiling so it's not so bad.

"Well... I calmed down and realized, that It's better to be your pet then die out there. And at least I need to give you chance."

"That's it? It was all just because you're thinking you are pet?"

"I'm thinking?"

"Yes, and you're wrong. You're not pet, you're a family member. Especially now, when you decided to trust me."

"After all you trusted me first... but aren't your methods of getting to know humans a little weird if you want them to be family members instead of pets?" She giggled at this.

"That's too long story for now. Now it's really late and we should go sleep."

"Just one last question." She looked at you, waiting. "You never wanted to eat me, am I right?" Her smile was enough for you.

"Of course, but I'm sorry. Maybe I scared you too much."

"Don't worry. It's past already, and at least now I know you're not some blood-thirsty wolf." You both laughed at this. Molly put you next to your bed.

"Goodnight Keane."

"Goodnight Molly." She left to her room and you lied down on your bed.
15111221222111.title: Big escape.

15112.content:
All four of the humongous wolves were packing up and did not notice your quarrel with the giant insect. You relax and thrust your trust knife back into its scabbard.

"Damn," you say to yourself, wiping the sweat from your brow, "too bad I'm too small for anyone to have seen that." You watch the wolves packing up for a few moments, glad that the man-eating behemoths are leaving. "Then again, maybe it's a good thing."

It's not until the father is staring the car up in the distance, the mother is rolling up the picnic cloth, the daughter is holding the basket, and the son is holding a few containers reluctantly that you realize something. Maybe you didn't want to think about it, but once the wolves turn their backs to you and head to their car the problem hits you like a sledge to the temple.

"H-hey! Wait!" you scream in futility, "Where the hell am I?!"

You take a step and reach out in their direction when you catch yourself, realizing that it's a futile endeavor. Moments later, the sound of doors slamming shut reached your ears and the car rumbled away in the distance, hidden behind the forest of grass

"Crap. Well, this sucks," you tell yourself. It had just sunk in that you were in the middle of a grassy—scratch that—you are in a HUGE grassy field, the equivalent of the middle of nowhere at your size, without direction and probably a slim chance of survival, given the creatures lurking in the grass.

"This is getting serious," you say to yourself, concerned. "I'm gonna be screwed if I don't do something...or find something. ...find...someone." Your head instinctively swivels as if trying to discern one direction as better from the others. It was all just a wall of green.

"Maybe I should follow that road," you offered to yourself. There was the sound of a car, you figured that there would be a road of some kind. Going in the direction of the giant wolves you had just hoped to avoid seemed a little silly, but then again, there were the small...ugh, fried humans in the bowl, which lead you to believe that human civilization must have existed somewhere in this world. With any luck, you could run into them.

Once again, you push your way through denser sections of grass that lie ahead of you in the direction that the wolves left, impeding your progress. An hour passed and you feel as if you had barely taken a bite out of the distance; the flattened grass that had been under the picnic really slowed you down. You guess that you may have slogged through about a mile, which would be, what, to those wolves five feet? Ah, you didn't stop to ask them their height to make an accurate estimate.

You are now caught in some real thick sh--stuff. Tall stalks growing high overhead as the thinner blades create a dense carpet, or rather ticket. You try with some difficulty to stay above the growth by stepping on the blades as they bent, but they had too much tensility and at one point your foot fell through and you came crashing down, swearing out loud, and forcefully pushed your way through in your anger.

Finding a small parting in the sea of green, you sat down, momentarily winded by the difficulty in progress.

"Man," your hand traced the handle of your knife, "I wish you were a machete. Or a bottle of water." You added the last part after a thought, when you realized you were thirsty. You hoped that a river would lie in your path before you died of dehydration. "...but then I have to watch out for monster-fish," you added vocally.

You cracked your knuckles and prepared to sludge through some more grass, when you heard a rustling in the distance.

"Uh oh," you breath.

You couldn't tell if it was moving in your direction and it didn't sound too loud, but the again, you couldn't hear a bug moving through the grass when you were big; might as well assume! You drew your knife and held it at ready in the direction of the rustling. Minutes passed and the sound did not cease. It had move slightly to your left and a little louder.

it started to make you nervous, especially when it stopped. Just stopped. Thirty seconds passed and all was still. You couldn't take it. It was making you paranoid and muttering under your breath wasn't helping. You had to scream:

"Come on out, Bugsy! I'll cut off all six of your legs!"

Then came--
15112.title: Stranded

choices: Ride in the back of the cruiser.
Cruise on the undercarriage into town.
151122.content:
It started as a low hum. In your concentration on the thing that was lying in wait somewhere in the foliage, you did not notice it until the noise was unmistakable. It was approaching very quickly.

Then it burst overhead, a blast of noise. A black shape roared overhead, sparing you no moment, but it was unmistakable.

You found your agility and flew through the foliage ducking and weaving round the grass blades. The rotorcraft was banking right into your path and you found out why. You soon had clear sight of a dirt patch ahead of you and hovering above, stirring up dust, was a black helicopter. It slowly descended until it's skis gently touched down onto the soil.

You could have jumped for joy, but then, right before you could celebrate your rescue, a shape burst out from the foliage and was making it's way to the chopper. It was a human! Suddenly the thought of one of those "first come, first served" routines popped into your head and you burst out into a run, not exactly on a trajectory to tackle the man dressed in brown, but the idea was what had you going.

But just then, the side door to the chopper slid open, and a man in armor was revealed and the first thing he did was raise a rifle and pointed it right in your direction. This was easy to tell since you weren't even close to getting between the man and the rifle's bullet path. Just before you could stop and raise your hands in fear, a muzzleflash from the rifle had you diving sideways just as hissing bullets passed overhead and ripped into the green behind you. A few of them a few feet shy of your body into the dirt.

You eyes had closed in fear. The soldier had only let off a burst, but you were left shaken and it took a few moments to roll onto your stomach and look up to see that the man in a uniform had already climbed in through the wide open side door. Once he was in the chopper began to ascend. The man turned around and shocked you when he looked right at you, smiled, and gave a salute. The door slid shut and soon after. You picked yourself up and watched the chopper accelerate and disappear into the horizon of green grass.

Your stomach twisted into a knot. In a strange world of great proportions, chances of survival nigh-impossible, and the first human encounter you have they shoot at you then leave...deliberately?! You stood up, unable to speak for a while and just stared into space when the chopper was. This development hit you as hard as one of those bullets would have and was left bouncing around the inside of your skull, scrambling your brain. You did what was to be expected:

"You stupid little bitches!" You whined, balling your fists as if ready to strike an imaginary person. "What the—? W-what the hell?! What about me?!" It took a great deal of effort not to collapse onto you knees and scream 'no' at the top of your lungs. But eventually, after taking slow, deep breaths and counting backwards from ten—about nine times—you calmed down enough to stop raging and forget about the helicopter, it was no help anymore. It just left you outlook a little more bleak; the wolves were dangerous, and now, what should have been your salvation, was also danger.

"Well, back to the road," you told yourself. You hung your head and heaved a sigh. You saw all the dirt your shirt and jacket had caught in your fall in the dirt. Finding your frustration again, you began to vigorously pat the dust out of your clothes. Just thinking about what happened was getting you steamed up all over again. Hell, you could hear the sound of that chopper leaving in your head. Yeah, and it was loud; you hoped that this wouldn't drive you crazy. The thought was just deafening and...

"Wait a minute..." you mumbled to yourself, "that's not a chopper." It really wasn't. This noise was not in your head, and it was not a helicopter. But it sure was loud, emanating a low rumbling noise. Your head swiveled all over the open sky, but there was not a thing to be seen.

Then suddenly a shadow was cast across the ground. Looking up you realized that the source of the noise had sneaked up behind you over the grass canopy and was blocking out the sky. The ground began to quake and you could not keep you balance. You fell on your back just as you were forced to clamp your hands over your ears once the rumbling had reached unbearable levels. Now looking up, you could see that you were directly over an enormous engine.

The noise the car was making kept you stunned, but mercy had it that the engine was killed soon after the vehicle had stopped. A clicking of a door opening sounded and you looked over to the what should have been the driver's side, and sure enough, two furry paws touched down on the ground. You followed them as move to the from of what was the car, with you yourself running up to see this stranger. It was a wolf alright, it would figure due to the size of the car. But, not only that, this wolf was dressed in black and blue; a uniform. It was a police officer. And he seemed to be concentrating on something... There was a voice so faint, coming from up above, that it was hard to hear unless you strained your ears. You could just barely make it out:

"...had 'em on here just a minute ago. What do you think?"

The wolf made a movement and then said, "WAHOOM!"

"Gesundheit."

The wolf sniffed, "Thanks."

You just made out the little human, also dressed in a police uniform, standing on the wolf's shoulder.

“What do you make of this? All readings are now showing negative.”

“I can smell exhaust fumes, other than those from our cruiser." The wolf replied to the human. "They’re faint, probably a kerosene fuel.”

“Are they flying jetcraft out here?” The other laughed.

“I don’t know, but whatever they used there’s no one here anymore," the wolf shook his head.

The other laughed, "Alright. Well, let's make a thorough sweep before we call it. Get the ground floor and use that nose of yours."

"On it like white on rice."

Uh-oh. They would be searching the area and would find you soon enough if you didn't act fast. Well, what should you do? Approach the police officers or evade them?
151122.title: Forsaken

choices: You were placed in a clear plastic container, that was big enough for one person
You were placed next to a set of human-sized car seats.
1511221.content:
There was only one thing for it; you needed to get to someplace safe, and the park wasn't it. Since this wolf worked with a human, maybe he'd help you. You gave a whistle, like you would if you'd been calling a dog.

The wolf turned his head, and pointed in your direction. "Someone's over there."

"Let me check it out," said the human officer. "If they're new, you might give them a heart attack."

"And if they're a Snack?"

"Tear their limbs off for me; I hate having to be Cloned after getting shot by them."

The wolf chuckled. "Alright." The wolf set the officer down.

Within a minute, the officer was within twenty feet of you, and he had a gun in his hands, pointed at you. "Hands up, and keep them up."

You had no problems complying with this.

"Anyone else here?"

"I don't know," you said.

The officer carefully approached you. "Was anyone else around a moment ago?"

"Some guys in armor," you said. "One had a brown uniform. The one shot at me."

"Those are Snacks, and you'd do well to keep away from them."

"Snacks?"

"They are our worse criminals, who are punished by getting Eaten and Cloned over and over," the officer said; he was now five feet from you. "Turn around, and put your hands behind your back."

"Why?" you ask, as you slowly turned around.

"Standard Procedure for people new to this world is to have a background check," the officer said. "If you check out fine, you'll get Registered, and Adopted by a Host Family."

"Host Family? Adopted?"

"A human can't just survive out here on their own; that bug blood on your pant leg should tell you that predators around here are on the large side."

"I guess that makes sense," you said. "And if I don't check out fine?"

"Depends on the crime you did," said the officer as he put a set of cuffs on you. "Might get eaten twenty times, might get eaten for an eternity."

"But, wouldn't getting eaten kill me?"

"Just the body you had at the time; that's where Cloning comes in hand," the officer said. "Everyone who's Registered gets Cloned upon an Unnatural Death, be it an accident, attempted murder, being torn to pieces by wild animals, or being digested." The officer gave a series of whistles, and you could feel heavy footsteps. "Let me do the talking; my partner can't hear you unless you have a mic-and-ears headset. Also, when he talks, cover your ears. Without protection, it's like being at the base of a Space Shuttle as it launches off."

The next thing you knew, you were scooped up in a large brown pad-covered hand.

"Get into a seated position," said the human officer.

You then watch the wolf officer walk up to the car, and open the door. Next thing you knew...
1511221.title: Apprehended

choices: You're shown one of those slide shows.
You're taken to the Police Department.
15112211.content:
The next thing you knew, you were placed next to something that looked like a pill box, with a person in each compartment. It was laying down, and resembled a series of mattresses. The people inside of them varied in look, and emotion. Some were scared, and were pleading to be let out. Others were clearly making threats at the officer, saying what they'd do to him when they were let out. And others still, as hard as it was to believe, were sleeping, or trying to. Their clothing varied as well from civilian dress, to military clothing, to something from the past, to stuff that looked futuristic. Some didn't even have clothing, or wore animal hides, with the fur still on them.

"What is this?"

"Segregated transport container," said the human officer. "Given that your neighbors could potentially be some of the most dangerous criminals in all the worlds known and unknown, you wouldn't want to be in an integrated container with them."

"I guess so."

"Now, before I put you into your own compartment, do you have anything you'd like to declare; weapons, drugs, medicines, personal items, that sort of stuff."

"Wallet in my back pocket, and a pocket knife in my front right pocket."

The officer took out your wallet. "These are no good here. If you check out fine though, you'll be given plenty of money; wolves put up good money to have good stock for their Tenants."

"Stock? Tenants?"

"They like to have good genes in those who live with them, and will offer good money for you to live with them, by your weight in gold."

"My weight in gold?"

"My partner offered me fifty thousand times my weight in gold so that I could live with him instead of my previous residence on the other side of town. Might not be as fancy, but at least I don't need to get eaten to show up at work on time."

"Eaten to show up at work?"

"Unless you've got schooling or a job, your default Cloning location is the place you're registered as living at; have a job or go to school, and you'll end up there then." He then pulled out your knife. "Did you kill a bug with this?"

"Yes."

"Would of been better off using a sharpened twig."

"I was caught by surprise. I mean, I'd just seen a family of wolves eating some people; it can mess with you."

The officer chuckled. "You'd better get used to that little detail; we all get eaten at some point." He then got on top of the container, and helped you onto it. He then more or less shoved you towards an empty compartment, and lifted the lid, like that of a coffin. He the walked behind you, and took the cuffs off. "Get in, and lay down."

You nervously gulp as you got in, and he closed the lid. He then opened a section that was ventilated. "You'll get your stuff back if you check out okay. Also, you'll be give a mic-and-ears headset then."
15112211.title: Pill Container

choices: The wolves get to you soon enough.
151122112.content:
And the wolf was finally allowed to open his mouth. The sounds came across as just a muffled noise, but from what the human officer described, it should have sounded like several supersonic explosions, on the outside that is. Hard to believe since you could see the wolf's mouth moving and all, though the thick layer of plastic should have been an indication of the protection your body had from the outside.

As surprising as it seemed before, to see those in the containers falling asleep, you couldn't help but get tired from the muffled screams of the other detainees and the bumping of the car ride. The two officers must have had some rounds to fulfill after you were picked up because it took a while and you ended up—well, maybe you were right, you couldn't get to sleep, but you did manage to space for a while. After all, your container's placement on the dash did allow a wonderful view of the sky.

Once you had finally arrived at the police station, the sky had become dark. A sudden jolt in movement had you sitting bolt upright, banging your forehead rather hard on the thick plastic as a result and eliciting an expletive from you.

"Rise and shine," came a voice through the slots.

"Gah! I'm up, I'm up!" you groaned, rubbing your head. Looking out through the clear plastic, you could see that the wolf officer was carrying the plastic containment apparatus through a set of doors, no doubt the doors to the police station as the other side had many more wolves bustling about wooden desks and even more miniature humans scrambling about the desktops.

"Welcome to the Station," announced the human officer just outside your capsule. "Unfortunately, we don't have time for the grand tour; maybe once some of you have been cleared. For now," he gestured downwards towards a system of steel compartments set on a table, "you will be detained until you either become Registered or designated as a Snack."

He opened up your capsule. "Come on, you first," the officer said kindly enough. Soon, he was helping you down through one of the doors built into each of the compartments on the apparatus. Dropping inside, the door closed slowly behind you, giving you the sight of the wolf and his human partner moving on to place the rest of the humans that they had gathered.

Looking around your cell, it was large enough to house one person with a cot set to the side to provide some comfort in those seeking rest. A set of iron bars was built into one of the four walls, though another steel barrier isolated you from the rest of the world. Four lights shining from all four top corners of the cell provided light.

"So this is it," you muttered to yourself, "reduced to a holding pen in the station." You put your hands onto the bars of the cell, feeling very much like a felon accused of a crime he did not commit.

Time seemed to pass by very slowly after that. Perhaps the officers were concerning themselves with the more conspicuous individuals of the group that had been brought in. You, meanwhile, had been lying on the cot, trying to find a way to kill time. The human officer, whose name you did not know, strangely enough, had taken away your knife, so you couldn't play pinfinger or slit your wrists. If it was anything that was killing you, it was the anxiety. Out of the wilderness and into jail, now waiting for a background check, however the hell they would accomplish that. And under what kind of criteria? Would they interrogate you? Would they read you your rights at all? Did your Miranda rights even exist in this weird place?

"Oh, this is—"
151122112.title: Detainment

choices: A wolf, and a human, who'd act as your counsel during your "interview."
A female wolf coming to pick up your neighbor.
1511221121.content:
"You alright in there kid?"

You look around.

"Over by the door, the right side."

You walk on over. "Who are you?"

"The name's Richard. Your's?"

"Keane."

"You alright in there?"

"I guess. This is my first time in a cell."

"Don't worry, once your family, or employer in my case, are called, they'll come and pick you up, and you'll be home before midnight."

"But, I don't have a family," you said. "I'm sort of new here."

"You'll soon get one," the person said.

"How?"

"The first family that you came across gets the privilege of claiming you. If they don't want you, or can't afford another Tenant, then things will get interesting."

"How so?"

"Families will bid on you."

"What?"

"They aren't buying you, mind you, it's the amount they are going to give to you, just to live with them, or equivalent value."

"What do you mean?"

"Price includes housing you, buying you food, clothing, paying for your education, as well as any deductions from paying Rent in Gold, as opposed to being part of a Meal for the Host Family."

"So, it's the amount that they are willing to put up to take care of me?"

"By your weight in gold."

"My weight in gold?"

"It's part of how humans are treated, and valued; in the Old Days, the more humans a family owned, the higher their status in society, as they were an indicator of wealth, especially those classified as Pets. Of course, even the poorest of wolves owned a thousand humans who'd been designated as Snacks."

"Pets? Snacks?"

"Let's just say that if you had a talent for making art, and I mean making something that took time and energy, like a painting, even a crude one, you'd likely end up as a Pet. If your only talent was causing trouble, you'd end up as a Snack, with no purpose other than to be eaten, especially during lean harvest times."

"And, how were those classified as Pets treated?"

"Well, better than pet mice I suppose, given the best of food that a family had, clothing on par to their Masters, and items to help them explore their creative thinking."

"And now?"

"The rights of most humans are the same as the wolves; vote in government, right to run for office, right to an education, right to a good paying job, and so forth."

"So, the Miranda rights exist here?"

"I don't know what those are."

"What happens if one gets arrested for a crime around here?"

"Well, one's allowed the right of counsel, recommended to keep their mouth shut, as what they say could be used against them, unless counsel is around, and to be informed of what crime they allegedly did."

"I guess that's about the same."

"Of course, there's your memories; those can be used as evidence, both against you, and for you."

"Memories?"

"It's part of the Registration, and Cloning, process; humans are injected with microscopic machines, and I mean microscopic on our level. These machines copy our memories, and store them in a file that's designated for that particular individual. Should you have an Unnatural Death, your clone will get all those memories, along with the ones you's made since, to about five seconds before your death, more or less depending on the situation."

"What do you mean by 'five seconds before your death'?"

"Do you want to remember getting your neck snapped when you're being prepared as part of a meal, or getting torn to pieces by a pack of hungry squirrels?"

"I suppose not."

"Good. And know this, when you get cloned, not if, you're still going to be you, but your body will be a clean canvas."

"What do you mean?"

"Let's just say that any scars you've got will be gone, along with other such things. More importantly, you'll revert to your most physically fit age, between twenty and thirty years old."

"That sounds interesting."

"Yeah, but it can be rough at times; watching members of your Host family grow old, and die, while you stay the same. Most tend to sign a DNC form after a century or so."

"DNC?"

"Do Not Clone. If they die afterwards, that's that. Buried in a matchbox in the garden with a daffodil bulb next to you."

"Why a daffodil bulb?"

"Flower grows every year, in remembrance of those buried there, even if the owner of the house fifty years down the line doesn't remember you."

"So, what about Snacks?"

"Mainly the worst of the Worst end up with that designation; murderers, rapists, homicidal and genocidal maniacs, and so forth. Of course, there are those who get designated as a Temporary Snack, but they'll get the full rights after serving their term, though it can take a while, and you have to behave during your term of being eaten over and over again, which can last up to a hundred years. But Eternal Snacks, like Adolph Hitler, Osama bin Laden, Ted Bundy, Timothy McVeigh, Pol Pot, and others like them, there's no chance of them getting their freedom, legally."

"But I was shot at by some people that the cop said were Snacks. How'd they get free?"

"Remember how your mother always told you to eat what's on your plate, and to not play with your food?"

"Yeah."

"Even more so with wolf kids and Snacks; more often than not, a Snack will escape because a kid forgot to eat them, and dropped them on the ground while picnicking. Normally their freedom doesn't last long; cops catch them, or they meet up with a hungry squirrel, and they get sent back to the Station, and end up with Additional Time on their sentence, unless they waited at the site, and didn't resist apprehension when a patrol came by. Then there are those who are clever; ambush human cops and park rangers, kill them, take their weapons, organize gangs, make vehicles, and generally terrorize human picnickers, and possibly worse."

"What do you mean?"

"A group tried to invade my home once; they wanted to kidnap the women and children to increase their numbers. Slight problem; there's nothing more dangerous than a man protecting his home, even more so when he has a lot of neighbors, some of which are armed with laser rifles instead of just M16 knockoffs. Of course, twenty intruders against a thousand men and women who know every square inch of the Human Quarters within a Home tend to be at a severe disadvantage. The Host Family really enjoyed breakfast that morning; we served them up rotisserie-styled. The police were just as happy to have them back in custody when their clones showed up at the station."

"So, what's with the wolves eating humans, and the cloning thing?"

"Let's just say that humans were easy for wolves to catch in the Old Days; still are actually. As for the Cloning, that's been around for ten thousand years, though the device to save memory came along about three thousand years ago, especially after humans who created art began to show up. As for whole process, they'd take a drop of the human's blood, or another form of DNA, and make a series of Blanks, whom they'd eat; even then they valued humans, especially good tasting ones, and wouldn't just eat them. As for the humans, they lived together, within the Masters' home, in what was essentially a pen. Now, they were taken care of; food and water, and social company, as well as a choice of mates, but it wasn't like they were free, even those who were Pets."

"So, how'd that all change?"

"Let's just say that there was a really bad drought about a thousand years ago, and food for wolves was coming hard to find. Don't ask me why, but some of these Pets asked their owner if they could be the Meal, and not just the Side, like they normally were. Turns out that Owner was related to the then-Leader of the time, and they suggested that to him. I'm not going to bore you with the rest of the details, but basically, those who willingly offered themselves up as food were granted the same rights as the wolves."

"But still, wouldn't the cloning process take up a lot of electricity?"

"The amount of energy it takes to clone a human, or a similar sized animal, is the same as if you'd turn a light on at your home, and I mean one on a human scale. Cloning a wolf sized animal though, that's a great deal more energy, enough to power a city block for a week, and I mean one for wolves."

"That doesn't make sense," you said. "Shouldn't it be like turning on their own lightbulbs?

"It's something about the fur; disrupts the system, or something," said Richard.

"Um, back to the memories thing; how do the police use them?"

"It's like watching a movie; they'll use a special screen to watch the Key Moments of you life, though they will look for criminal activity. Your safest bet is to be honest, let them know if you remember something or not, or what you do remember of it. Of course, I doubt you'd be in too much trouble, doubt you've done much more than just steal candy or pull on some girl's hair."

Then, you began to hear heavy footsteps coming in your direction. You look and see that it was...
1511221121.title: Prison Conversation

choices: A wolf, and a human, who'd act as your counsel during your "interview."
Another "Inmate" began to talk, but he isn't as friendly.
15112211212.content:
You look through the bars as a well-dressed female wolf came by your table. She looked into your neighbor's cell, and smiled, placing a finger next to it. You watch as a couple of arms came out between the bars, and wrapped around it. She gave a nod, and a officer came by, with a set of keys. You then heard the clinking, as the cell door opened.

"Here's your headset," the officer said. "You'll have to put some clothes on when you get home."

"Thanks," said Richard as he came out.

You blush at the sight of him; the guy was naked, aside from a headset that one of those X-Box live players would use, and covered in what looked to be olive oil. He turned and looked at you, flipping the mic up towards his one ear. "Be careful around little kids; they don't always eat what's on their plate, and might leave you at the park, especially if you're Take-out." He then flipped the mic down. "Mic check."

The wolf woman gave a thumbs up.

"Take me home."

The woman set down what looked to be an opened matchbox, and you watched Richard get in. "Alright, close the box."

The woman closed it part way, leaving only his head poking out. She then walked to a wolf officer, and talked to him. After a little while, she signed a form, and placed what looked to be gold coins on the desk. The officer put the coins in a box. "Make sure that you have a chat with that kid's parents; imagine the trouble if the kid had forgotten a Snack instead of a Willing Meal." The woman nodded, and walked out of the Station.

You sigh, and sat on the cot.
15112211212.title: A female wolf coming to pick up your neighbor.

choices: "I think you'd better speak for him yourself."
151122112121.content:
Some time later, a male wolf walked up to your table, and stopped in front of your cell. You gulp a you look at him; he had that look, the lawyer look. The wolf set a hand down on the table, and a woman stepped off of it. She also had the lawyer look. She got out a clipboard, and walked up to you. "Detainee 236805, please state your name for the Record."

"Are you talking to me?" you ask.

She looked at you. "My partner and I have been assigned to be your counsel, so yes, I am talking to you."

"Oh."

"Your name?"

"Keane, Keane ________."

She then asked you how you spelled your name, and you told her.

"Alright," she said. "You'll address me as Mrs. Torrance, and my partner as Mr. Halftail." She then turned to the cell officer. "Open his door, and bring him a headset."

Within a minute, you were on Mr. Halftail's palm, and Mrs. Torrance was by your side, asking you questions, and writing the the answers down.

"To the best of your knowledge, have you been convicted of a crime?"

"No, but I've been in School Detention before."

She chuckled. "Who hasn't? When you were apprehended, was anything taken from you?"

"My wallet and pocketknife."

"Describe them please."

"Wallet was brown, had my school ID, and a $10 bill, a $5 bill, and five $1 bills. The knife's handle was red, and had a white cross on it."

"Swiss?"

"I think so."

She then asked you some more information, a little bit about your family, how you were in school, and other such things.

"Now, did officer William ask you anything?"

"Are you talking about the guy who arrested me?"

"Technically, they didn't arrest you, more like detained you. Your freedom might have been taken away, but you weren't charged with a crime."

"Alright. Well, he did ask me if I'd met up with anyone else."

"And did you?"

"Some people the officer said were Snacks; they shot at me when I tried to go for their helicopter."

"Avoid them like you'd avoid a spot that had a bad tooth; they'd rob and murder you, if not worse."

"Kinda got the message from them."

"That's good to know." She looked over the information. "Well, from what I can tell, you'll be allowed to leave within a day or so, with a Host Family."

"Alright," you sighed. "By the way, the guy who was next to me said that people were allowed to have firearms."

Mrs. Torrance chuckled. "Can't kill mice with a knife."

"Mice?"

"Mice, rats, squirrels; you don't want a colony of rodents nearby, especially if you plan on having children; the DNA of an unborn baby isn't exactly on file you know. Also, you don't want to get eaten by them; sooner get impaled on a child's tooth than get torn to pieces, at least your death would be quicker from the tooth going through an artery."

"So, have you been eaten?"

Mrs. Torrance smiled. "Of course; being a Willing Meal is how I paid for collage."

"Well, how does that work?"

"Depends on what you're to be part of, and the preparation; if the method of cooking isn't going to kill you, the assistants give you an injection, one that keeps you from feeling pain, as well as from moving your limbs- the client is expected to use chopsticks, or the tips of their claws, you pick you up, place you in their mouth, and swallow- death tends to come from drowning in the stomach acids. If the method of cooking, or preparation, is going to kill you anyways, the assistants twist your head, fracturing the vertebrae, making the death quick and painless. In either case, you're given a very good massage before they inject you, or twist your neck. Snacks don't get either of those though; they feel every bit of pain."

"Every bit?"

"From being dropped into boiling water, to being dissolved in stomach acid; they also remember their deaths, up to the last moment. Tends to break them."

"I'm surprised that a lawyer would condone such practices. I mean, they are human beings."

She looked away. "Some don't deserve to be called human."

Halftail placed a finger next to her face, and she grabbed a hold. "Focus on the here and now, Kate. You need to be strong."

"You're right Patrick. It's just, you know."

"Do you think that you can keep it together for our client's sake, or do you want me to speak on his behalf myself?"

Mrs. Torrance said....
151122112121.title: A wolf, and a human, who'd act as your coun...

choices: You pass, and go through the process of Registration
1511221121211.content:
"I can keep it together," she said. "I don't feel like taking off my clothes just yet."

Mr. Hailftail chuckled. "Good, cause I don't want to do a one-handed neck-snap either. Of course, I got a snack here to satisfy any immediate hunger pains."

You watched as he stuck his free hand into a pocket, and pull out one of those pill container things, only this one didn't have a mattress in each section. Each of the individuals were shouting things out, vulgar things, and all of them were naked. Then, he opened the lid on one of the compartments, and the man inside tried to get out, but Halftail would carefully tip the container one way, and the other, keeping the man in it, as he raised the container to his mouth. With a quick flick, he caused the man to tumble into his mouth. He then tilted his mouth from side to side a few times. Then-

Well, after you realized that he wasn't just going to swallow the man, you decided that it was best to look forward, and not watch blood drip down your lawyer's lips. You could hear the bones as they cracked and snapped.

"Make sure that you wipe your face," said Mrs. Torrance. "And don't forget to rinse out your mouth."

"You're worse than my mother at times," Mr. Halftail said.

"Someone has to be one to you." She then looked at you. "Word of advice; never get on the wrong side of a wolf. They don't like it when someone hurts a friend of theirs."

"I got that impression."

A little while later, you were in a room, and set on a table. There was one of those restraining-type chairs, as well as a doctor-like person, and a couple of officers. You look at Mrs. Torrance.

"Get in the chair," she said. "The doctor's just going to take your blood, and inject the nanobots into your body."

"Are you sure that this will be safe?"

"Of course. Now, get into the chair."

You go and sit in the chair. The officers fasten the restraints, and the doctor puts a couple of needles into you. A while afterwards, both your lawyers, and the officers were watching some screens. Then, the questioning started.
1511221121211.title: "I can keep it together."

choices: Spend the night at Mr. Halftail's place, with Mrs. Torrance and her family
Spend the night in a cell.
15112211212111.content:
"Alright," the one officer said after like an hour. "You're clear to go and go through Registration."

"I was getting worried there," you said as the other began to unfasten your restraints. "You guys kept on me about that shoplifting thing."

"Just don't let your thieving career extend beyond that," the second officer said.

"I don't plan to."

"Just remember to come in if we apprehend those Snacks who shot at you," said the first officer.

"If I can," you said.

"If you have trouble getting to the Station, call us, and we'll schedule you in. After that, have someone in your Host Family snap your neck, and you'll end up here."

You rub your neck at the thought. "I hope we don't need to do that."

"Alright," the officer said. "Now, we just need to put you up for the night; you can spend the night here, or at your counsel's place of residence, until such time as a suitable Host Family comes to claim you."
15112211212111.title: You pass

151122112121111.content:
A while later, Mr. Halftail had taken you, Mrs. Torrance, and many others, to his home, where he was promptly greeted by a female wolf, who looked like she was expecting a cub or something.

"Long day?" she asked.

"Sort of," Mr. Halftail said as he opened up the carrying case you were in. He then carefully picked you up and placed you in the woman's paw-like hand. "New client."

Mrs. Halftail sniffed you. "Good scent; I wonder how he'd taste fried up and dipped in chocolate."

You cringe, and try to get away.

"He's staying on Business, not Residence," Mr. Halftail said as he picked you back up. "He's new to this world to." He then whispered to you, or tried to. "Pregnancy cravings; I'll be glad when those are over. Last night she had stuffed Ghost Peppers with French dressing drenching them." He then set you on a shelf with Mrs. Torrance. "I guess I'll try your concoction."

Mrs. Halftail chuckled. "You'll like it."

Mrs Torrance chuckled as she lead you to what looked like a mouse hole. "Another four months of strange preperation methods." She then lead you through a series of alleyways, until you got to her door. "Time to meet the family."

You found out that...
151122112121111.title: Spend the night at the Lawyers

151122112121112.content:
You were just about to open your mouth when the doors to the room opened and in stepped a female wolf wearing a white, three-quarter sleeve, button-up shirt. She had dark fur and bright yellow eyes looking through a pair of glasses onto a clipboard held in her hands. She looked up and asked, "Is number 236805 present?"

"Right here," you replied, waving your hand.

She nodded, "Your presence is requested in the testing labs." She turned to Mr. Halftail and Mrs. Torrence, "I'm afraid he will not be leaving today, counsel, if his stay has already been arranged."

"No, actually, we were just getting to that." Mrs. Torrence then looked at you with a puzzled expression. "What is this additional testing for? If I may ask."

"The Head of the Cloning Department has discovered an unusual mutation in the subject and wishes to further examine them." The wolf turned the clipboard around and tilted it so that Mrs. Torrance could see. "As you can see, he was very specific." The gesture must have been intended to discourage her from attempting to extricate you from any unnecessary procedure. In fact, you admired how she was trying to make things easy for a newcomer like you to reenter a new society, even when she breathed a sigh of defeat as she read over what was written on that paper. You couldn't read the strange text, but Mrs. Torrance looked at you again, this time with an expression you could not place.

This had you scratching your head nervously.

She chuckled, "Oh, I'm sure it's nothing. After all, the scientists are trying to make all sorts of advances in cloning technology and every bit of information on human genetics helps." She smiled reassuringly, "I'm sure they'll be done with you within a few hours."

Mr. Halftail stood up and looked down at you and said, "I'm sure we will meet again, tomorrow, when it's time to select your host family." And with that, your counsel said their goodbyes and left through the doors.

The wolf with the glasses lowered her paw down to the table and smiled at you. "Well, hop on."

"Thanks," you replied and stepped onto the giant digits and made you way for the big palm pad. Once there, the wolf lifted you gently up into the air and curled her clawed fingers up, forming a protective barrier should you have fallen, once she started moving. Passing through the halls, you got to see some of the police station. This was the first time you had been further than the lobby of one, but the spartan interior and dull colors would seem like the standard design. Occasionally, an officer wolf would pass by carrying one or more humans in their paws, all of them well-behaved unlike newcomers or snacks. Things were getting quiet; you figured it must have been close to midnight.

The two of you passed through a set of double doors. Inside was a small room with a large, sturdy table upon which was an assortment of human sized medical equipment, mostly gurneys with some sort of machine next to them and a few pieces of radiology equipment. Among them was a human male who looked to be in his late thirties, waiting patiently for your arrival.

The wolf lowered her paw to the table and you stepped off, but spared a moment to glance back at her. Oddly enough, she was looking back and smiling.

"Thank you for escorting Number 236805 here, Ms. Shirana," the man spoke

The wolf momentarily regarded the man with a look of disdain, but it was fleeting and she nodded respectfully before taking here leave.

"Hello, my name is Dr. Lazarski." The man proffered his hand, which you shook. He didn't even ask for your name as his eyes went to a clipboard he was holding. You told him your name, but he didn't even look up, and just hummed a confirmation. There wasn't even any preamble with him as he got right to the testing.

"We will have you lay down on that right there." He pointed to a sort of gurney constructed out of a frame with fabric stretched across it with a hole cut out for a persons head and many restraining straps.

"Okay," you said approaching the strange contraption. You could tell that you were supposed to lay face down in it even before Lazarski told you to do so, after you were told to remove your shirt. Once you were on it, the doctor began to pull straps across your back and securing them tightly. After a few moments of adjustments he asked:

"Are you comfortable?"

"Surprisingly--yes," you replied.

"Can you move at all?"

You gave a few experimental tugs here and there. "Not an inch," you confirmed.

"Good."

"Say doc, what is this thing for?"

"Oh, just to restrain restrain patients while we extract some tissue samples for study." You were kind of worried when you felt a pinch at your spine. "Right now, we are doing bone marrow..."

"Wait. Bone ma--AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA!"

<><><><><><><>

After several more tests, you and Dr. Lazarski were heading back to your cell. The things he put you through left your body feeling exploited. Most of them were just scans and such, but you did not let go of that first one.

"I'd say that session went quite well, don't you?"

"That was a nasty, dirty trick!" you complained indignantly. "A sneaky, sneaky trick, and I hate you!"

"Wonderful to see your energy return so quickly. Here we are," he said once you reached your cell. The doctor ushered you inside and the bars slid closed once more. Without a word, the doctor left. You certainly did not like the guy, but you realized just how fatigued you were as the sight of the cot in your cell became surprisingly welcoming. Falling face down into the mattress, you groaned loudly.

It would be sometime before you finally managed to sleep, but the rest was wholesome.

Until...
151122112121112.title: What's, uh, the Deal?

1511221121211122.content:
You had completely forgotten about the headphones that covered your ears. They were unnoticeable most of the time, but it was a different story when you wound up on your side during the night, they ended up pressing uncomfortably into the side of your head.

By that time you could not fall asleep again. However the spartan accommodations of the cell did not exactly accommodate early risers, such as yourself. You resolved to rest a bit on your cot, slipping into a pocket of your imagination to pass the time. In fact, this secluded cell that they put you in nearly had you forgetting that you were in a world that was several times your size, and you left your to mind wander in a state of half-dreaming.

As you layed back, hands behind your head with your eyes closed, you thought of inconsequential things like music in cinematic sequences of your imagination, and eventually listening to the soothing sound of an ocean lapping against a sandy shore. It was so subtle that it took you a while to notice that the sounds were played through your headphones. It must have been something to put newcomers at ease, and honestly, it worked as you found yourself enjoying the nostalgia of. . .

Some kind of "Klip-klapping" sound invading the privacy of your--'what the hell?'

Your eyelids fluttered open for just a moment to see the figures of half a dozen men in uniforms of black and grey standing around your cot. No doubt these guys had marched in while your earphones only picked up ocean noises, in fact they were barely audible. Someone must have tampered with your 'phones. Your expression must have been one of incomprehension, but no one cared to elaborate.

One of them looked at you and then made a gesture of his fist hitting the palm of his other hand. Your mind was a few milliseconds too slow to register the fist of the other soldier that wound up to strike at your face.

POW!

You feel weightless for a moment, but then your body begins to pick up speed, your stomach lurching at the acceleration, and through the haze you the the ground fast approaching. You don't shield yourself and just let your body slam into the ground and you find it somewhat comfortable. It was solid at first, but the dirt started to suck you in, squeezing just right around your body and feeling cool against your skin. It felt nice.

These things don't last.

It started as a buzzing in your ears. It grew louder and louder until it caused pain. You tried to move, but your body just wouldn't respond like you wanted it to, so you just sucked in a breath between your teeth in pain. What you got wasn't air. A foul liquid sprayed into your lungs and made you hack and choke. You struggled to get up, but found your body in pain and unwilling. Your eardrums were on fire and your head hurt like hell, and the ground held you under.

Then you felt something grab the scruff of your shirt, hauling you to your knees. You spat out the mud that had gotten in your mouth and breathed in air, but it was still all over your face and when you tried to open your eyes it dribbled, painfully, into them. Whoever had pulled you up now roughly wiped a hand against your face, getting some of the mud off, though irritating your eyes. They burned, but you blinked, which hurt, but the tears washed away the filth and a blurry image of a man yelling at you registered in your mind.

That buzzing noise. You could see his mouth move, but it was hard to hear. You must have been deaf. The sound that came through was loud and urgent, though that could have been discerned from his frantic expression. You weren't feeling too good right now; to hell with what he wants. Your head was throbbing. You ran your hand across your skull, but something seemed to be missing. You pulled your hand away and the part that passed over your ear had a little red on it.

That's what it was you were missing your helmet.

It had to be somewhere. You turned around, and there it was, lying a few feet away in the mud. Unable to manage getting up yet, you crawled over to it, ignoring the pain in your back. Once it was within reach, you reached out for it, but your hand looked different this time. It looked stronger, more mature, and it wore a green sleeve. But this was your helmet, you were sure.

You tried to place it on your head head, but lost balance and fell back down. You lifted your chin to keep your head above the muck, and with your headache clearing you got a good look at what was happening. You were surrounded by jungle, the dense foliage that surrounded you from all sides was cleared only by the expanse of dark mud. But the mud was also stained by something darker. A few feet from where you laid was a mass of red, twitching and leaking blood into the water that crept slowly outwards. A crater was directly beside what used to be that body, and just a bit more behind that was half of one, legs practically gone, stomach shredded open and intestines spilled into the muck.

The hands of the other man, a soldier, hauled you back up, this time to your feet. His mouth was right next to your right ear as you could barely make out:
"You've got shrapnel in your back, but we've gotta get moving!" He shoved something into you hands. He faced you, the man dressed in green, it was hard to hear again, but his lips said "We'll come back for them...need to find the team..." something like that. He was running now, waving his arm at you to follow him. You looked down and see that he had given you your rifle back.

Alright then, no time to argue. You could hear the distant chatter of gunfire now. It was getting more distant...and more...your vision became unfocused. You were dazed and confused from the...

Your mind finally snapped back to reality and the images became fuzzy like a dream. You felt a hard surface below you and realized that you must've been dreaming, though your head did feel like a jackhammer had done a number on it and your nose felt a little numb too.

"Ugh. What a horrible nightmare...", you groaned. You started to stretch your limbs when you realized something:

"Wait a minute... Oh God!..."
1511221121211122.title: Give Me Shelter

choices: Still in your cell at the police station
Someplace other than the police station.
15112211212111221.content: You couldn't move. You rolled your eyes around, trying to figure out where you where. After a while, you realized that you were...
15112211212111221.title: "I can't move!"

choices: Get a week's worth of rest.
151122112121112211.content:
You figured out that you were still in your cell, just as the door opened.

"Are you alright?"

You roll your eyes, and see a woman in a doctor's outfit come in. "Are you okay?"

"Something's wrong," you gasp out. "I can't move."

She turned her head. "Two Human Guards."

Two men in police uniforms came in.

"I want you to carefully roll him on his side, and I want you to lift up his shirt," the doctor said. "I need to see what that hack did to him."

The one guard carefully rolled you onto your side, and the other pulled up your shirt.

"Wolf shit!" the doctor growled. "A simple blood workup would have sufficed, not bone marrow extraction!"

"Will I be alright?"

"You'll be just fine," she said. "Once you....
151122112121112211.title: Just a dream

choices: Right into a room filled with others.
151122112121112212.content:
It was pitch black and it felt colder than it had been back at the station. That’s how you knew that this was not your cell anymore, as if your throbbing headache and the numb feeling in your face was not indicative enough. You remembered something about getting punched in the face, but that was as far as your memories would assist you, growing murky between the events of some kind of armored guard in your view and your current position on the cold ground.

You were lying on your back with your arms drawn tightly behind you. Moving any of your limbs gave you the indication that several straps restrained your arms and legs as they pressed harder into your skin. They were uncomfortable in that position and felt numb and asleep, but you couldn’t pull them out from under your back and neither could you pull your legs apart and only caused the individual strips of binding to press uncomfortably into your skin.

You tried to distinguish anything from the dark—a wall, a desk, the corner of the room, anything which could help orient yourself. But minutes passed and your eyes could not adjust to the dark, there just wasn’t any light. Wriggling around frantically, you tried to find a weakness in you bindings, but they held fast and all you managed was rolling onto your stomach. In doing so, your nose bumped into the ground, something which was surprisingly painful. Pain exploded in your face and elicited a whimper followed by some loud profanity. Your nose was broken.

Too soon did a light illuminate the room, for your eyes complained immensely at the photon intrusion, squinting before the bright rectangle that illuminated the room from one of the walls. It was a door. The silhouettes of people mercifully dampened the effects of the light, but it was not within their interests to make you comfortable. Two people moved in, and though your position on the floor and the look on your face must have been one of the most pathetic imaginable, they roughly hauled you to your feet and held you up.

"Ow! Wassit!" you complained, unable to speak clearly due to clogged nasal passages. You looked from one guard to the other, noting the grey armor and the masked faces and the creepy polarized eye lenses. One of them raised a handgun to your cheek, effectively shutting you up.

“Sit him down,” commanded a voice, a low and distorted one, though you thought it had a feminine quality to it.

It came from within the room via speakers, as it came from all around in a hollow, distorted tone. You were in no position to argue as the two men who had you by the arms forcefully pushed you into a chair you had not seen in the dark. Once you were seated, the door closed and it was dark again, but only for a moment, for shortly after another light, thin and rectangular, outlined a reflective surface. It was like a mirror, but you realized that it must’ve been one-way glass.

“Number 236805,” the voice stated, “For any further designation of yourself, your are to be referred to and refer to yourself as Number one-sixty-two from now on, is that understood, subject 162?”

Rather than argue with the disembodied voice, or fear of bringing about the wrath of the two guards beside you, you lowered your head in defeat and answered, “Yeth...Ma’am?”

“Good,” the voice said; at least your assumption was right. “Why do you think you are here, Number one-sixty-two?”

You just entered this strange new world with the sheer amount of change throwing your brain for loops so sharp that the Blue Angels couldn't handle them, yet this question really blindsided you. Why did you think you were here in the current company? How were you supposed to know? Before you answered, you took a second to hock out a big, fat, dark-red blood clot, making it easier to talk.

“Why do I think I’m here? I think I’m here because I’m a human the size of a freaking mouse on a planet with giant wolves!” Just answering that question made you feel stupid.

“Actually, that is incorrect,” the voice replied.

“Huh?”

“You are here because we believe that your genetic structure is anomalous,” the electronic voice said. “Normally, we wouldn’t collect you until evidence of your anomalous existence was incontrovertible, however, with you it is a little different.” After a pause, the voice continued, “Your anonymity to our detection systems and body composition tests seems to be part of your anomalous nature.”

“What in the hell are you talking about?” This voice was making you feel like you did something wrong, but you knew you were the victim here. “I don’t know anything about—”

“So,” the voice interrupted, “let me assure you that it is within your best interests to come forward with any knowledge you may have about your abilities.”

“Listen—!” you nearly jumped up, but backpedaled when the cool steel of a muzzle pressed into your back threateningly. “Uh, you’ve got to have the wrong guy!” you said shakily. “I don’t know anything about any abilities!”

“However, the time for you to confess any knowledge of your existence will come later; Mr. Lazarski requested that we restrict any investigations into your—” You were sure the right side of your face twitched at the mention of that name. Another outburst stopped at your teeth as you caught your breath when the gun pressed a little harder into your spine. "—anomalous properties to any other staff. Testing on you will be done at his discretion."

A moment of silence followed. The guards hauled you back to your feet, and still holding your arms they untied your legs.

"Welcome to Site 17," were the voice's parting words as the guards then led you out the door. You moved into a dimly lit hall with concrete walls and metal floors. You moved a bit drunkenly with your dizzy head and recently bound legs, but your guards were there to keep you balanced, though you did not want to look back, sure that their weapons were still at the ready. They led you briskly. . .
151122112121112212.title: You're Gonna Fade Away

1512.content:
It was a human man, around your height. He seemed to be in his early twenties, and looked like he was scared. Also, he was naked of clothes. Thing was, he looked somewhat familiar to you, like you'd seen him before, but you couldn't place where.

"Do you understand English?" you ask.

"I understand," he said in an accent that seemed strange, yet familiar. His voice also seemed eerily familiar.

"Alright," you said. "Let's see about getting away before those wolves spot us."

"Good idea," the man said.
1512.title: It's a human at the same size as you.

choices: A Shadow coming over the two of you
15121.content:
However, just as you made a few steps away from the wolves, the man jumped you, putting his hands around your neck.

"Like you're going to turn me into the Authorities, Jude," he said. "No one pulls the wool over the eye of a wolf like me!"

That was when it finally clicked- the man a a younger version of Adolf Hitler. You begin to struggle, and try to scream for help, even from the oversized wolves. Eventually, things become dark due to....
15121.title: The man's not your Friend

choices: Uniformed Giant Humanoid Wolf, like the family was
151211.content:
"I don't think you want to harm him, Snack!" said a deep voice.

"Nein! Nein! Sie werden es nicht machen mich zu ihnen!" Hitler said, in a fearful voice.

"Get him!" the voice said.

You feel Hitler's weight disappear from your back.

"The punishment for your crimes was to be a Snack for a hundred years for each man, woman, and child you caused the death of," the voice said. "Guess we'll have to clone you for an additional hundred years for the attempt on this one."

"Nein! Nein! Nein!" came Hitler's screams.

"Take him back to that family, and ask them to come down to the Station," the voice said. "After all, their Snack attempted to take the life of a Person."

You get to your knees, and see that your rescuer was a.....
151211.title: A Shadow coming over the two of you

1512111.content:
It was a human, one wearing some sort of uniform.

"Are you okay?" he asked.

"I've been better," you aid, as you rubbed your throat.

"At least we got to you in time," the man said. "Otherwise, trying to figure out what you were would have been trickier."

"What do you mean?" you ask. "I'm human, like you, and him, though I guess he's not our most shining example."

The man chuckled. "No, the question is, are you a Snack, or are you a Person?"

"What's the difference?" you ask.

"A Person can live out their life," the man said. "Snacks get eaten. Like him!" He pointed towards the wolf family.

You look, and you see a wolf wearing a uniform similar to the man next to you, holding a squirming, and screaming, Hitler between two of his claws, engaged in conversation with the parents. The father looked at the boy, and said something to him. If anything, the boy looked embarrassed. The uniformed wolf gave Hitler to the father, who in turn gave him to the son, who then placed Hitler in his mouth, and swallowed.

Once again, you felt sick.

"Another two billion years," the man said. "If not longer."

"What?" you ask.

"Murder someone, and you're a Snack for a hundred years," the man said. "Thing is, you get the memories of your previous copies- get eaten enough times, and you break to just a shell of your former self."

"What do you mean?" you ask.

"We have the ability to make Flash Clones of people," the man said. "Useful for certain kinds of work, and especially useful for those our size. Die of causes other than Natural Ones, you just wake up in a tube at the hospital. Thing is, your DNA has to be on file, or it won't work. As for criminals, we make sure they serve the full sentence."

"But why do you let them be eaten?" you ask. "Wouldn't it be easier to just kill the likes of him?"

"True, but the families of the victims wouldn't have true satisfaction with just one death," the man said. "Besides, wolves have to eat too. Gives them an easy meal. Of course, one could actually be a Work Snack, there are those of that temperament around here."

"I don't think I'll get used to the idea of it though," you said.

"Don't matter," the man said. "Have to take you to the Station though."

"Why?" you ask.

"To get you checked out, like all who come here," the man said. "Now don't worry. You'll be taken there by....
1512111.title: Uniformed Human

15121111.content:
"You'll be taken there by my partner and I," the man said. "Once we figure out what you are, one of two things will be done with you, have you labeled a Person, meaning that family will take you to their home as part of the compensation that they owe you for almost letting their Snack kill you, and care for you until a more suitable Host family can be found to take you in, or you'll be labeled a Snack, and cloned, over and over again, and eaten, over and over again, until your sentence is served, at which point you can live out your life, until you die of Natural causes that is. Of course, you don't look like you've done anything too serious, except perhaps some candy stealing, so I doubt you'll be labeled a Snack."

The man looked up and made a sharp whistle. You look up to see the uniformed wolf looking down at you.

"WAHOOM!" the wolf said in a voice that was so loud, you were forced to cover your ears. The man looked at you, his own ears covered, and his face was one of concern. He then looked up, and whistled again. After that, he tapped his ears, and mouth. The wolf's eyes bulged, and he put a furry hand over his own mouth, and nodded. He then motioned with his hands and fingers.

"He says he's sorry for hurting our ears," the man said, as he rubbed his.

"What?" you ask, as you wiggle a finger in yours.

"Without the right protection, it's like being right at the base of a cannon when they talk right at you," the man said. "As for us, except for a sharp whistle, they can't hear what we say."

"Then how'd you talk to him when you got Hitler off my back?" you asked.

The man pulled something out of a pocket, and tossed it to you. "That will help you."

You look at the object. It seemed to like those headphone that people wore while listening to Ipods and other such things. There was even a mic on the one ear thing. Since it seemed similar to those, you were able to figure out how to put them on, especially after you unwound the cord that connected the two earpieces together.

"He'll sound a lot better now," the man said, as he put his own on. "Alright Samuel. Ears are Safe. Mic Engaged. Can you hear me?"

"Mic Working William," the wolf said, in clear English.

William looked at you. "Say something."

"Like what?" you ask.

"His mic's working," Samuel said. "Guess I best start taking you to the Station."

"It's not like we could just walk there you know," William said with a chuckle. "Oh, and what's your name kid? Need that for the Report."

"It's Keane," you said.

"Not a bad name," William said as Samuel more or less, scooped the two of you up with his furry hand. "And I bid you welcome to our fair world."

Samuel then walked towards....
15121111.title: My Partner and I

151212.content:
Eventually you black out and Hitler gets off of you.

"Eine weniger Juden zu töten. Nun, um zu sehen, ob er etwas Sinnvolles hatte," Hitler muttered as he began to search your pockets. He finds your wallet with your ID. "Verdammt Amerikaner." He tosses it. He then finds your pocketknife. "Dies ist nützlich." He looks back at the wolves, who seemed to have heard something. "Sie werden nicht zu essen mich diesmal." He then sneaks off, as the wolves begin to look around.
151212.title: You Black Out

choices: That you're in a snack container, wrapped in a napkin
You're in some sort of tube, with Human doctors nearby, and with wolves in back
1512121.content: Your head hurts. Your body hurts. You try to move, but you're unable to. The pain is agonizing. You begin to hear voices, but they sound muffled. Finally, you manage to open your eyes, and you see...
1512121.title: You're Alive

15121211.content:
When you open your eyes, you find that you're in something that look like a snack container, and you've been wrapped in a human-sized napkin. What's more, the wolf girl was looking right at you.

"He's awake guys," she said, her voice reverberating through the sides of the container.

"That's good to hear, Molly," said a female voice.

You look around, and see that the family is in some sort of vehicle, and the father seems to be driving it. You then look back at the teenage female. She seemed to be worried about you. Was this the same wolf who'd joyfully eaten another of your kind just a little while ago? Then another thought came to you; they were saving you to eat later!

You start to struggle, trying to free yourself of the napkin.

"Easy little one," Molly said. "We're not going to hurt you. We're just taking you to the hospital to make sure you're alright."

"Let me go!" you shout. "Let me out of here."

"You need to stay in there for your protection," Molly said. "If I take this lid off, my voice will cause your eardrums to burst, and you could die."

"You're just going to eat me anyways," you mutter.

"No, I'm not going to eat you," Molly said.

Your eyes bulge. "You heard that?"

"No, I can't hear you," Molly said. "Wolves can't hear humans when they talk- something about the soundwaves not reaching our ears. However, I can read lips very good, along with emotions and body language. However, I will be able to hear you once we get you a mic-and-ear set- it will allow you to hear us without harm, and us to hear you when you talk to us."

"Why'd you eat those other humans?" you ask.

"They were criminals," Molly said. "It's part of their punishment. But don't worry too much- their clones will be processed soon."

"Cloning?"

"It's something that has come in handy," Molly said. "It makes sure that you'll be okay in case of an accident, and that us wolves will have plenty of food to eat, even in a famine harvest."

"What do you mean?" you ask.

Molly smiled and said...
15121211.title: Snack Container Transport

choices: The Family Arrives at the Hospital
Molly tells you More about this World
151212111.content:
"Many humans have jobs as willing meals," she said.

"What?" you ask.

"It's a good paying job for your species, especially for a first job," said Molly. "You're paid your weight in gold, if not higher."

"You're sure about that?" you ask.

Molly nodded. "I had a Summer job at a restaurant. Waited on tables, and served meals to wolf customers, mainly ones with humans. You guys are a very important food staple. Average wolf eats about fifty of your kind a day."

"But doesn't that kill humans?" you ask.

"Yes, and so it would, if it weren't for the cloning process," Molly said. "Once your DNA is in the system, you'll be cloned upon the event of an Unnatural Death, be it from being accidentally stepped on, falling from a great height, or most anything else, including being digested by stomach acids."

"Still it sounds painful," you said. "They're being burned alive by acid. That has to hurt a great deal."

"And so it would, if Willing Meals weren't given injections that kept them from feeling pain when they are used as part of a meal," Molly said.
151212111.title: Willing Meals

choices: English, but accented with heavy Russian traces
1512121111.content:
Before Molly could say anything else, he father said, "We're here."

Molly looked at you through the container's walls. "Don't worry, if anything's wrong with you, the doctor's will see to it that your needs are taken care of."

"What happens after?" you ask.

"We'll have to take care of you, as part of your compensation."

"Why?"

"Because it was one of our Snacks that attacked you," she said. "Because of this, by Law, my family is required to provide compensation, be it by paying your hospital bills, giving you gold, or most anything else that could be covered by the Fine my family will have to pay to you."

"Well, I guess I could use a place to stay," you said. "Could that be part of it?"

Molly smiled. "That could be arranged."

As she opens the door of the vehicle, you take a look at the place she was carrying the container towards. It was a white building, with a strange red symbol, that looked like a man in a lotus position inside the jaws of a wolf.

Molly looked at you and said, "You'll be fine here."

She and the others walked into the building, and you see a young female wolf sitting at the Check-in Desk. She looked up at the mother and father and asked, "What can I do for you?"

"You might want to get a human doctor," the father said. "Specifically one who deals with head and neck injuries."

"Oh? What's the reason?"

Molly placed your container on the Desk.

"He was attacked by a Hitler clone," the mother said. "One we'd bought for our son to eat during our picnic. He forgot to eat it."

The clerk looked at the boy. "Billy, this isn't the first time I've heard about such things," she said. "You should know better than to play with a Snack. Willing Meals are one thing- they don't cause trouble if you don't eat them. Snacks on the other hand do." She then looked back at the parents. "Have you notified the police of the incident?"

"Not yet," said the father. "Thought that it was more prudent to get here as soon as we could in case he's more seriously injured than he looks."

The clerk nodded. "He's not in the System to be Cloned then I take."

The mother shook her head. "I doubt you'll have to worry about that Hitler clone though; we were picnicking at the park, and you know about the squirrels they have."

The clerk chuckled. "Pesky little things," she said. "Have to make sure that my Tenants stay close to me, especially the pregnant women, when we are there."

"Yes," the father said with a grin. "By now, he's probably in some den, in four or five pieces."

"They do like to eat meat," the clerk said. She then pressed a button on a microphone. "Dr. Orloff. Paging Dr. Orloff."

From the speaker nearby was a voice that was in...
1512121111.title: The Family Arrives at the Hospital

choices: Bad news. You have a Slow Leaking blood vessel in your Brain.
Good news. You just need a few days rest, and to just take it easy.
15121211111.content:
"Chto vy khotite, vy negabaritnykh durak?" said a voice that was in loud Russian. "YA zanyat!"

"Must be in the bathroom," the clerk said. She pressed the button on the microphone. "U nas yestʹ patsiyent s travmoy shei ivozmozhno sotryaseniye mozga."

"Deystvitelʹno? YA budu gotov cherez desyatʹ minut," said Orloff.

"Vy by luchshe sdelatʹ eto pyatʹ!" the clerk responded. She looked at the parents. "Do you know what language he speaks?"

"Molly's been talking to him," the mother said.

"He seems to speak English," Molly said. "At least, that's the impression I got from the way his lips move when he talks to me. He also seems to understand me when I talk to him."

"Alright, that that will make things easy for most of the staff," the clerk said. "Not that it would be a problem if he spoke something else."

The father chuckled. "In that case, you'd better tell your friend that I took Russian in School in addition to the Mandatory Sign Language class."

"He's never easy to deal with," the clerk said. "The transition in coming to this world was rough on him, but he's good at what he does. Knows how to read the brain-scanning machines, and all the others."

"He'd better," the father said. "Kind of need to know if we'll need to eat the kid or not."

You felt scared at the father's pronouncement.

Molly looked down at you. "Don't worry," she said. "You'll be fine. If the worse come true, I'll be the one to eat you. Within the hour after that, you'll have been cloned, and be at a tube for us to pick up."

"We'll see to to it that you're taken care of dear," the clerk said. She picked up your container and placed it on a shelf. She then pressed a button. "Patient with neck injury and possible concussion. Bring a stretcher." She then opened the lid on the container, carefully grabbed you, pulled you out, and placed your still napkin-wrapped body near a small door.

A moment later, some human doctors came out with the stretcher. They took you inside the wall, and everything looked like a normal human hospital, with white walls. As you looked around, you were quite shocked. Most everyone seems between the ages of twenty and thirty.

"Guess he's new here," chuckled one the doctors near your legs. "Were you told about the cloning process?"

"Yes," you said.

"Did you know that your clone will be at your most physically fit age?" asked the one by your arm.

"I wasn't told."

"It's true," the one by your legs said. "I was born over sixty years ago."

You blinked. From what you could see, the man looked like he wasn't even twenty-five.

He chuckled. "Paid for collage by being a Willing Meal. Good enough gig, I still do it when I need to make some quick cash. Of course, if nothing's going on here, I'll put my name on the list for Hospital Food. Not glamorous, but it does the job, and pays the bills."

Less than a minute later, you were in a room, where a thirty year old looking man was standing by a machine.

"Polozhite yego na koyku," he said.

"You might want to speak English around this patient, Dr. Orloff" said the doctor by your arm, as they transferred you to a cot-like thing on the machine.

"Kak ya damKapitalisticheskaya udovletvoreniyem uslyshav menya govoritʹ po-angliyski," Orloff said with a growl. "Nazhmite na knopku."

"Just because you came from Cold War Soviet Union, doesn't mean you can't be nice," the one said as he press a button.

A moment later, you were going through a tube of some sort.

A few seconds later, you saw Dr. Orloff looking at an image, and pointing at various sections, and talking to the others. "Skazhi yemu," he said as he left the room.

"What's going on?" you ask.

The one doctor looked at you and said...
15121211111.title: Loud Russian Doctor

choices: Wait it out, and be cloned afterwards
151212111111.content:
"It's not good," the doctor said.

"What do you mean?" you ask.

"I'm not going to get into all the technical details," the man said with a sigh. "However, your assailant damaged a blood vessel in your brain, and you're bleeding internally. Basically, you're a ticking time bomb. Personally, I'd suggest that you get your DNA on file so that you can be cloned, whether you prefer to just wait and die from the bleeding, or if you prefer to let a wolf eat you. Either way, you'd keep on living on, as a clone."

"And if I didn't get my DNA on file?"

"Matchbox and Daffodil Bulb, Incineration, Donation to Science, or get Eaten would be your Funerary options," the other doctor said. "Otherwise, you've got less than twenty-four hours to live."

"Could you cut me loose from this napkin?" you ask. "I'd like to think about it."

The two doctors looked at each other. "Might as well," said the one.

The other went to a desk and got out a knife. "Not my first time cutting a napkin wrap."
