A while later, you were sitting in a chair on a shelf in the waiting room, with something called a mic-and-ears set, which looked like the headset that people who played with others Online with X-Box and Playstation type games used to talk to each other. This would allow you to talk to the wolves, so that they could hear you, and allow them to talk to you, without blasting your eardrums. Molly was sitting by the shelf. The look on your face was enough for her.

"That bad?"

"I'll be dead by this time tomorrow," you said. "Unless I put my DNA in the System and go through with the cloning process."

"You have a nice voice," she said. "It would be a shame to not hear it more."

You blush at this. "I haven't heard anyone, except my music teacher, say that about my voice."

"I have a good ear for that sort of stuff," Molly said. "So, what's you name? Kind of need that if I want to call you something other than human."

"It's Keane," you said.

Molly smiled. "Nice name, though I'd hate to have to write it on a stone for you and put your body in a matchbox with a daffodil next to it. Especially if it was your only body. Of course, if you get your blood in the system, I wouldn't mind burying it, providing that your clone is there to watch it."

"You'd really like for me to put my blood in the system?" you ask.

She placed a finger next to you. It was easily half your height. She then carefully touched your face, and wiped some tears you had. "Yes," she said. "You're a good person, I can smell it in you."

You sigh. "Alright, I'll put my DNA in the System."

She smiled. "That's good to hear."

An hour later, you were back on the shelf- a doctor had taken your blood, and your DNA was being processed into the system. Also, a special chip had been injected into you, one that would copy your memories within two more hours, and have it transferred to those for your future clones.

"Well, at least you're cloneable now," Molly said.

"Yeah, but what to do now?" you ask.

"Well, you could wait until you do die," she said. "Or you could let me eat you. The doctors could inject with the full body anesthesia and such once your memories have been uploaded, and then I'd eat you."

"Are you sure that it would be painless?" you ask.

Molly smiled. "I've eaten humans most every day, and the Willing Meals I've had don't really have any complaints. Most more or less drown first before the acids burn their bodies enough to actually kill them."

You chuckle at this. You decide to...
151212111111.title: Ticking Time Bomb

choices: Waking up in a Cloning Tube. The fall had killed you.
Landing in some sort of liquid. Molly's Stomach Acids.
1512121111111.content:
"Well, if it will get this whole thing over sooner," you said. "I guess I'll let you eat me."

"I wouldn't too much about the whole thing," Molly said. "I'll even tell you the Process: First, you'll have to take your clothes off, that way you'll have them later. Next, you'll take a bath, to make sure that you are clean. Third, the doctors will inject you with the solutions that will keep you from feeling pain, and will prevent you from moving on your own. Forth, they'll rub you down with olive oil, so that you'll go down my throat a little easier than you would otherwise. After that, you'll be placed on a plate, which will then be sent to me. Once that happens, I'll say a quick prayer for you, pick you up with a pair of chopsticks, place you into my mouth, and swallow. The landing itself ought to be enough to kill you if I don't have enough stomach acid to slow your impact. Otherwise, I suggest that you try to swallow some of my acids- it will help to kill you quicker than just merely drowning would."

"You might want to know that I'm afraid of the dark," you said. "As well as confined spaces, especially in combination."

Molly chuckled. "You'll see light soon enough after I eat you."

"You also realize that I'll be naked." You blush as you think about it. After all, she wasn't your mother, or your younger sister who forgot to knock on the door on occasion, or even a girlfriend.

Molly smiled. "It's not like I haven't seen a naked male human before," she said. "After all, I've eaten plenty, both male and female. The clothes shouldn't be eaten."

"I guess I can understand that," you said with a nervous chuckle. "It's just that, I'll probably scream. That's how afraid of the dark and confined spaces I am."

Molly chuckled. "I doubt I'll be able to hear it, if that's what you're worried about. Of course, we'll see about getting you help with that after you've been cloned."

A few hours later, you were on a plate, naked, before Molly. Your whole body felt funny, in that you couldn't feel anything, or physically move anything that was a voluntary muscle, and you were all oiled up. Molly gave you a slight smile, placed her hands together, and said her prayer, most of which you couldn't hear too well, due to how loud her voice was, but part of it that came through her hands was, "May he come back quickly, and whole." She then picked up the chopsticks, picked you up with them, and opened her mouth. The sight of her dark maw was enough to make you scream your lungs out as she dropped you onto her tongue. You tried to move, and attempt to escape as her jaws closed, but were unable to do so. You couldn't help it. You had always been afraid of being confined in dark spaces. Molly then tilted her head upwards slightly, and swallowed, causing you to tumble off into thin air. The next thing you recall is...
1512121111111.title: Fears about being eaten

choices: A pair of Police officers, one human, one wolf.
15121211111111.content:
You woke up, and found yourself in some sort of capsule-like device.

"Il est réveillé," said a voice.

You hear a woosh sound as the capsule opened.

"Cloning successful, like normal," said another voice. "No mutations in genetic material. Memory Uploaded, minus Five Seconds."

Two sets of arms come in, and pull you out, and help you stand. A man held a pen in a vertical position in front of your eyes. "Have your eyes follow this." It was a familiar test of visual acuity; follow the object. You watch as the pen moves to the left, to the right, and slowly all over. "Very good," he said

Another man came over and he had a tongue depressor. "Dites-ahh", he said, as he held out the depressor.

"What did you say?" you ask.

The man chuckled. "On dirait un chat n'a pas la langue de cette personne."

"It's quite obvious he can speak," said the first doctor. He then looked at you. "He wants you to say 'Ah'."

"Alright." You open your mouth, and let the French speaking doctor examine your throat.

"Il est bon," he said as he tossed the depressor into a bin marked "Bio-Hazard".

"Look like you're good," said the English speaking doctor. "You have a clean bill of health."

"Don't you have machines for that?" you ask.

"We do, but it's best to double-check. Never just rely on a machine."

"So, why doesn't your friend speak English?" you ask. "There was also that Russian doctor, um, Orloff."

"Because French is my native language," the French doctor said in clear English. Then he reverted back to French. "Je serai toujours parler quand je peux."

"One tends to learn a few languages around here," the English speaking one said."I can speak five others, and understand a further ten.

"Um, what was that Minus Five Seconds thing earlier?" you ask.

"We find it best that one doesn't remember the exact moment of Death," the English speaking doctor said. "Instead, we try to make it a seamless transition to waking up, as if getting up from a dream. Apparently, Molly Sixclaw-Whitetail had a fairly empty stomach, and the landing shattered your skull, snapped your neck, broke several of your ribs, which pierced your lungs, and other injuries related to a fall of over thirty feet. Death was instant."

"I guess I wouldn't want to remember that," you said with a nervous chuckle.

"Good." The doctor then handed you a set of hospital robes and a mic-and-ear set. "Put those on. You've got visitors."

A while later, you were "dressed" enough to be taken to a visitor shelf, where you find out that your visitors were...
15121211111111.title: Cloning Tube and Languages

choices: The Police want to talk to you.
151212111111111.content:
Molly was right at the side of the shelf. Her parents were talking to a uniformed wolf, one that looked like some sort of police officer, with Billy standing between them.

"Looks like the cloning was successful," she said with a smile.

"Does the process fail at times?" you ask.

She chuckled. "It's been a long time since there was a serious failure," she said. "About the most common 'failures' that occur are a little extra body fat, or muscle, depending on the latest food fad, or the amount of exercise one's been doing, or junk food they've been eating."

"So I'm guessing that a good diet and healthy exercise are encouraged for humans," you said.

Molly nodded. "I like a little bit of fat for taste, but a girl does have to keep her figure."

"I don't think you'll get to eat me too often," you said. "You have no idea how scared I was."

"All humans are scared when they first get eaten," Molly said. "One would wonder what was wrong with them otherwise. You'll get used to it though."

"Not to the dark though," you said. "Or being trapped."

"There's more to this than what you're saying."

You sigh. "There was an old mine shaft near where I lived, been abandoned for as long as anyone living could remember. Me and my brother liked to play Miner or Treasure Hunter down it. One day, one of the old support props gave way. My brother was on the side towards the opening. I, on the other hand, was trapped in the dark, with no way out. Let's just say that, after I was rescued, I had to leave my bedroom door open partway, with a nightlight on, and I was twelve at the time, a little old for such things, but that's how badly affected I was."

"I guess that's why your screams were of a higher pitch than those of most I eat," said Molly. "However, I can promise you that I'll help you through it, both with getting used to being eaten, and with the fear of dark confined spaces."

"Do you mean that?" you ask.

Molly nodded. "I give you my word, even if I have to do all of the work myself."

You then looked towards the one wolf. "What's he doing here?"

"That's Officer Samual," Molly said. "He and his human partner, William, are conducting the investigation, trying to find Hitler, and sort out the punishment we'll have to take for letting him go free."

"And what's the punishment?" you ask.

"Billy owes you roughly a hundred times your weight in gold each month you live with us," Molly said. "We're also responsible for helping to pay for any medical bills, cloning bills, education, and so on. It's next to nothing for us, but you'll be set for quite a while."

"Sounds good," you said.
151212111111111.title: Admitting Fear and Restitution

1512121111111111.content:
A while later, after the doctors had preformed a final check up, to make sure that your new body was in fully-functional working order, you'd finally be able to get something to eat. It was a ham and cheese sandwich- it seems that your one earlier observation was correct, there were indeed animals on your scale, and these animals were also cloneable. There was also animals on the Wolves' scale, but these, and the Wolves themselves were not cloneable- from what Molly had told you, the energy required to clone you had been the same for her to turn on a light, barely noticeable, but to clone something that was the size of a wolf required a whole lot more, easily the same amount that a whole block used in a week, if not more. Essentially, the meat that the wolves ate came from human-scaled animals, including humans themselves.

When you were done eating, Molly placed something that looked like a human-sized matchbox next to you. "When you're done, you might want to get inside," she said. "This way you'll be more comfortable than you would if we used a Snack Container to take you home." She then opened it and you took a look. It was basically what it looked like- only it was padded on the interior, without any matches, or a striking surface. It also had a clean smell, a little too clean. It seemed more like a coffin than a way to transport people.

"Is this what you normally use to transport humans?" you ask nervously.

Molly gave a nervous smile. "Not normally," she said. "Normally you'd be transported in a special carrying case, but we didn't think that we'd encounter a new human."

"So, what do you normally use these for?"

"To bury your kind in, should you have an Unnatural Death," she said. "Your bodies produce good nutrients for the plants."

"Are you sure that this will be safe?" you ask. "You know that I'm afraid of dark and confined spaces."

"I'll keep it open part way," Molly said with a more natural smile. "That way you can see what's around you."

A while later, you were in the matchbox. Strangely enough, it was comfortable, more comfortable than your previous transportation container.

"So, do we have to Foster him ourselves?" Billy asked. "I'm not in the mood for buying him clothes and food all the time."

"That would be what you'd deserve," said Mr. Sixclaw. "Just be glad he ought to be satisfied with room and board, in addition to a hundred times his weight in gold."

"Yeah, all from my allowance," Billy muttered.

"Billy, we've told you time and time again that you're supposed to eat Snacks, not play with them," said Mrs. Sixclaw-Whitetail. "This time you'll have to face the piper, and pay for your actions."

Billy looked at you and growled. "Perhaps I ought to eat him without knocking out his pain receptors, and tear him to pieces."

"No wonder the Tenants prefer to live near my room instead of yours," Molly muttered. "You'll never get the house if you only see them as Food."

"Is he always like this?" you ask.

"Aren't all little brothers that way?" Molly asked with a smile. "He's just upset at being caught, and the fact that he'll have to take a flea bath tonight."

"Flea bath?"

"Mom had us take a check-up while we were waiting on you," Molly said with a grin. "The one doctor found fleas on him, but none on me."

You chuckle at the thought. If these wolves were anything like your dogs, they might enjoy taking a bath, but add in the scent of that flea killing soap/shampoo, and they'd clear on out of the house.

"You said that you've got Tenants," you said. "Do you have others like me living with you?"

"Of course we do," Molly said. "Hard not to have any. They check on things, and help to keep small issues, like mold and leaks, from becoming bigger, and more expensive to fix. One of the couples we have should be able to care for you, at least for the next couple of years."

"Well, how many do you have?" you ask.

"Oh, not many," Molly said. "Just a few.....
1512121111111111.title: You go to Molly's Home

choices: Molly takes you to her room before you see anything else happen
You end up watching the process.
15121211111111112.content:
"We have four thousand, two hundred humans of Rent-Paying age," Molly said with a smile. "Of course, we've got around ten thousand who live with us, most of which are under the age of eighteen, and therefor, don't have to pay Rent."

"And just what is Rent?" you ask.

"Five times their weight in gold per week, or be part of at least one meal each week," said Molly. "You'd be surprised as to how many do both."

"Both?"

"Oh yes, your kind needs us, and we need them," Molly said. "Many wild animals see you as an easy meal, especially the park's squirrels. That Hitler clone has probably met up with some. Without our cloning devices, your kind wouldn't last long, even as a species."

"And why does your kind need us?" you ask.

"In short, you're easy to clone compared to a creature near our size," Molly said. "Your kind has been coming to our world for many millennium. Sometimes you saw us as Gods, sometimes as Demons, and more often than not, you were nothing more than a bite to eat for poorer wolves, or a pet to the wealthy."

"You mean, your kind would just eat us?"

"More like catch and breed you for food," Molly said. "We thought nothing of it, you were extremely primitive then, nothing like art, or clothing to talk of, let alone anything else."

"We've been coming that long?"

"Yes, but then several thousand years ago, we noticed a change in the new ones that came here," Molly said. "They could create art, primitive, but it was art. Instead of just seeing you as food, the 'gifted' ones were bred as pets. Of course, we were way ahead of your kind on a technological level, in that we were using electricity to light our homes while you still lived in caves. Along the way, Cloning, and Flash Cloning were developed, but they didn't do much, other than the cloning of better tasting humans meant that one didn't have to rely on genetics too much any more, one one could clone the same human over and over. Still, we watched your kind develop. Eventually, some very gifted ones came here, ones that could write. Things began to change after that, slowly of course, but they happened, especially once we found a way to 'save' your memories, and transfer them to new bodies. That's sort of how you're alive, fresh new body, but with a lifetime of memories. Of course, talking to your kind was no good- trouble hearing on both ends. However, some did sign language, and we began to use that to communicate, in addition to writing. It wasn't until we began using sound transfer devices that someone stumbled on a way in which we could talk to each other effectively, and mic-and-ear sets developed as a result."

"So, how do you see us now?" you asked.

"We see the ones that behave themselves as People," Molly said with a smile. "Those that don't, are Snacks."

About thirty minutes later, the family arrived at the home. It was way bigger than any mall you'd been in, or had memories of at any rate. It's size made you look at Molly, and try to calculate her height. She had to be around three hundred feet tall, if not more. The house had to be a thousand feet tall at any rate. Small wonder her kind had thought of humans as food for so long.

Her family opened the door, and she walked in, with you still in your matchbox container. She then set you on a table, and let you out. She pointed towards something, a bunch of shelves, where you saw a whole crowd of people. "Meet our newest Tenant, guys," she said. The people waved at you, many with a smile on their faces, especially the females near your age.

"You can get to know him later," said Mrs. Sixclaw. "Who wants to pay Rent by being part of tonight's supper?"

A couple hundred step forward, and begin to take their clothes off, along with the headsets, while Mrs. Sixclaw went to the cupboard. One of the things you saw her set on the counter made you shudder; it was a meat grinder.
15121211111111112.title: One House Equals One Small Town

choices: Go Pick up a Book to Read
151212111111111121.content:
Then next thing you knew, you were surrounded by a leathery pad, and lifted from the table. "I'm going to take Keane to my room, so that he can pick out a place to stay at for the night," Molly said. "Besides, I don't think he's ready to see our sort of cooking yet, mother."

"Understandable," said Mrs. Sixclaw. "Just make sure that you're ready to help set the table, and you find someone to share the meal with him."

"Yes mother." Molly then began walking.

Some minutes later, along with a set of stairs and one door opening and closing, Molly opened her hand, and tilted it, causing you to land on a wooden desk.

"Is she going to grind those people up for your meal?" you ask, nervously, as you try to stand on your own two feet.

"You've had ground meat before, right?"

"Yes, but the cow was never alive when it was ground up," you said. "I mean, she's going to grind them up while they're alive, isn't she?"

Molly chuckled. "There isn't enough of a knockout medicine to keep them from feeling that pain, or that much fear, without ruining the taste of the meat," she said. "She'll kill them first."

"Kill them?"

"By snapping their necks," Molly said. "If the method of preparation is going to kill them anyway, we like to make sure they're already dead. At least, that's the way it is with Willing Meals, or some such thing. Snacks though, we don't bother killing them, or giving them painkillers."

"They still get cloned, right?"

"Of course," Molly said. "In fact, they'll all be finished being cloned by the time supper is ready."

"Wouldn't you have to go to the hospital to pick them up?" you ask.

She shook her head. "Most every home that has Tenants has their own Cloning Chamber," she said. "Get you registered as residing here, and this will be your Default Cloning Location, or DCL. Of course, once you are registered for school, or a job, you'll be cloned at those places during school/work hours."

"I guess that's good to hear," you said.

"The only annoyance is that you might want a change of clothes," she said. "Depending on the circumstances of your death. By the way, would you like to read something until they call us down?"

"I wouldn't mind," you said.

She smiled, inserted a few claws into a long crack on the desk, and lifted up a whole case of books, one that was six feet tall, and over a hundred feet long.

"That's a lot of books," you said.

"Over two thousand titles, not including translations in German, Russian, French, Spanish, and Wolven."

"Wolven?"

"Its what we normally speak when humans aren't around," Molly said. "It's a little difficult to put the various subtleties into human words, as there's the tone of our voice, and even the scent that we give off. It's like a bunch of growls, howls, yips, yaps, wolfs, and barks to you; even if you knew what each sound meant, you wouldn't get the whole message, unless you could read the scents we gave off, along with the meaning of the tone."

"Then, why write it out?"

Molly chuckled. "The written version was easier to translate than the spoken one for your kind."

"Then, why did you speak English back in the car when I first woke up?" you ask.

"Well, you are of obvious European blood, and your ID thing was in English, so we spoke it, hoping that you'd be familiar enough with it to understand us."

"And the Clerk at the Hospital?"

"It's the Primary Language there," said Molly.

"Just how many languages do you know?" you ask.

"I can speak and write three others fluently, in addition to Wolven and English," she said. "But I can understand another sixteen, both the written, and the spoken versions."

"How do you get the time to learn more than two?"

Molly chuckled. "One listens."

"You said that you read my ID," you said. "Do you have the rest of my stuff?"

Molly got out another matchbox, and carefully set it on the table. She opened it up. "Would have buried you with them if you hadn't made it."

You sighed. "I still didn't make it. I mean, this body's nothing more than a copy."

She put a finger under your chin. "It still has your heart and soul," she said. "Those in and of themselves are more important than your memories."

"How do you know this?" you ask.

She pointed at a landscape drawing of the house, one that seemed to be from a human's point of view, looking up at the eves. "Let's just say that your Earth, is not the only Earth out there," she said. "And let's also say that the Hitler who killed you, is not the only Adolf Hitler who resides here on this world."

"What do you mean?"

"The Hitler who made that drawing never got involved in politics, or into the whole anti-Jew thing," Molly said. "Wouldn't be too surprised if he takes it on himself to Foster you, and take care of you."

"Why would he do that?" you ask.

"He feels bad for what his other counterparts did- imagine being an artist one moment, and finding out that one who shared your identity had murdered a million people the next. He even contemplated signing a Do Not Clone form and just taking his life. Grandpa talked him out of it."

"Still, how do you know about the soul being the same?"

"We made Blanks of them both, clones without memory, and woke them up in the same room, with nothing but a set of painting materials. The clone of the Artist decided to decorate the walls with paint. The Butcher used the blood of the Artist."

"Ow!"

"Yeah."

You then decide to....
151212111111111121.title: Molly's room

choices: You have similar tastes in books
You have different tastes in books
1512121111111111211.content:
You decide to look through your things- the books could wait a few minutes.

One of the first things you pull out was your wallet. In it was a picture of you and your younger brother and sister; the three of you had been swimming that day, and all of you had forgotten to put on sunscreen. Then there was a picture of your mother and stepfather- well, you'd known the man long enough that you'd called him father on occasion. Finally, there was a picture of your father, in a military uniform. He'd gone overseas, and had been killed in the line of duty, while trying to protect the men under his command.

The next thing you pulled out was a pair of pants and a shirt; that was then you realized that you were still wearing a hospital gown. You look at Molly. "Um, mind turning around, please?"

"I've already seen you naked," she said.

"Yes, but I want to keep a limit on that."

She chuckled, and turned around.

A couple of minutes later, you were decently dressed. "Alright."

She turned back around, and looked at you, with a grin. "You do have a nice body," she said. "I can't wait to see how you actually taste, without olive oil, or anything else."

"I don't want to think about that," you said, as you search through the rest of your stuff. "Are you sure you got everything?"

"Everything I could find on you, along with most other items around. Why?"

"I'm missing my pocketknife," you said. "He must have taken it."

"I could buy you another knife," she said. "And a better one at that."

"It wouldn't be able to replace this knife," you said. "It was a gift from my father, passed on down from his father, and his father before him."

"I'll ask the police to look for it," Molly said. "Now, let's try reading a book. I like it when Tenants read to me."

"Alright," you said, as you walk to the bookshelf.
1512121111111111211.title: Go through your Stuff

choices: I get more enjoyment out of listening to a story, than reading it myself.
It's more affordable to buy them human-sized.
15121211111111112111.content:
As you look over the titles, you see some that most teenage girls would have in their rooms. "The Twilight series?" you ask, as you look back at Molly.

"Go Team Jacob," she said with a grin, as she raised a fist in a cheer.

"You do realize she marries Edward in the end."

"I know, but one has to root for a wolf when they themselves are a wolf," Molly said, with a chuckle. "Is one of them the one you want to read?"

"Um, no." You look at some more, and see ones you actually like. "Treasure Island?"

"I like pirates, and Action/Adventure stuff, not just sappy romance."

Then you see some you really like. "The Dragon Knight series! I own all nine of these," you said, as you look at all nine of them; you wish that Gordon R. Dickson had made number ten. "And the Redwall Series! I have all twenty-two novels" She only had fourteen.

"Wait, you've read all twenty-two of them?" Molly asked.

"Of course," you said. "Though, I wish that Brain Jacques hadn't died of a heart attack; I'd of liked to meet him."

Molly began to laugh, as if something good had happened. "I've been hoping for this." She then dashed to a computer, turning it on. "Let's if they're in the System."

"What are you talking about?" you ask.

"Any book you've read, or any movie you've seen, will be copied, and available for sale," she said.

"What?"

"They're copied from your memories," she said. "And if it's a new book, or a different version of another story, people who like stuff made by the author, or the original story, are notified about them."

"Seriously?" you ask.

"More importantly, you get a percentage of the money made from it," she said. "As for the rest, that goes to those who share blood ties to that person- though for the most part, that tends to be people from parallel worlds."

"Alright," you said, as you grab Redwall itself. "Let's read Redwall."

"Give me a moment," Molly said. "I'm ordering the human-sized books."

"Are you ordering them in your size?" you ask.

"I don't bother doing that," she said.

"Why?" you ask.

She looked at you with a smile. "Because...
15121211111111112111.title: Similar Tastes in Books

151212111111111121111.content:
"I just get more enjoyment out of listening to a good story," she said. "That way I can imagine how the characters in them could look."

"Really?"

"Let's take Matthias from Redwall and Mattimao. In Redwall, I can picture him as something of a clumsy teenager who only won the fight against Cluny through basically luck, in that he cut the rope holding the Joseph Bell, and because he was partially possessed by the spirit of Martin."

You chuckle at this. "Yeah, he was lucky in that fight."

"But when his son was kidnapped some years, or should I say seasons, later, he actually knew what he was doing, but he still almost lost his life fighting against the Wearet."

"Still, one has to admire those Redwallers and their allies- plenty of heart, and willing to fight to protect their friends and family," you said.

"That's why I like the series," Molly said. "The main characters might be tiny mice, but they sure do have big hearts. Just be careful with real rodents on my size scale- they'd eat you alive, without knocking out your pain receptors."

"I hope you don't have any of those here," you said. "I mean, getting eaten's bad enough- don't want to feel any pain."

Molly flashed you a toothy grin. "They don't live in occupied houses long, especially duel-occupied houses."

You chuckle nervously. "Right, let's get to reading this story."

"Let's," Molly said, as she got on her bed.

"You should know that she doesn't just picture how the characters look," said a voice above you, and to the left. "She likes to picture them naked, especially the males."

You look up, and see sitting on the edge of a shelf, a teenage...
151212111111111121111.title: Talking about Redwall

1512121111111111211111.content:
The person was a teenage Asian girl. She looked at you with a smile. "It's nice to see that the new Tenant likes the same things we do," she said as she got up, and went to a ladder.

"Come on, Lilly," Molly said with a chuckle. "Do you have to spoil my daydreams? Besides, you often wonder what they'd look like too."

Lilly chuckled as she climbed down the ladder- there had to be fifty feet between the shelf and the desk.

"Are you safe climbing down that thing?" you ask.

"I wouldn't worry too much," Molly said as she sat up on the edge of the bed. "If she falls, I'll catch her. If I fail to catch her, she, and everyone else, is in the System."

"But, what about her body?" you ask.

"I'd probably eat it, and clean up the blood with disinfectant."

"She would do that," Lilly said as she finished climbing down.

"Um, why are you called Lilly?" you ask.

Lilly chuckled. "My parents named me Rirī Lǐ lái gōngsī, or Lilly Lilly, though my friends like to call me D-Lilly."

"Wait until you meet up with her parents," Molly said. "Her father was in the Japanese Imperial Navy, and her mother was in the Chinese People's Liberation Army, until they came here. Thing is, there's not much use for humans to be in the military, as there really isn't any need for one."

"So, how did they end up marrying?" you ask. "I mean, they were on opposite sides during World War Two."

"They had other husbands or wives before they hooked up," Lilly said. "It's sort of encouraged actually- be with someone until the child is of age, and then start seeing someone else."

"It's a bit of holdover from the Old Days," Molly said. "Back then we wanted as much genetic diversity among our human stock; we still do actually- we don't want the gene pools to grow stagnant."

"I guess I can see how that's helpful," you said, as you picked the book back up, sat down, and start reading. However, your eyes tended to drift towards Lilly; she had a nice body from what you could see as she walked up and sat next to you. She was a head shorter than you, and wasn't the sort to be featured in a magazine, but she was well proportioned.

Eventually, it was time for dinner. You ate with....
1512121111111111211111.title: Lilly

15121211111111112111111.content:
When it was time for dinner, you decided to eat with Molly's family. Lilly might have been nice, but you weren't too sure how her parents would react to her bringing a strange boy to dinner, especially an American.

Lilly had laughed at this, but seemed to understand your concerns, as she climbed back up the ladder to the shelf. "Alright," she'd said. "I'll tell them about you."

Molly had then picked you up, and let you watch as she walked down to the dinning room. Along the way, you observed a series of shelves. "It's part of how the Tenants get around when they aren't in their area," Molly had said. "Otherwise we'd have to carry them everywhere. Thankfully, they've got their alleys and such that they can use for traveling between the walls and the floor spaces."

After a minute, she'd arrived at the table and set you down. "Stay here," she said. "This is my place. Hopefully Billy won't try to grab you."

She then set the table, along with her mother. As she did this, you noticed what they were going to eat; burgers with a side of slightly fried humans- the burgers had been made with those who'd been grounded up, and thankfully, the fried ones were dead.

You're slightly startled when she placed a plate next to you. She smiled at you. "Your burger will be made with beef, and your fries are made with potato slices."

Mrs. Sixclaw then placed the burgers on buns, and began serving them, just as Billy and Mr. Sixclaw came in for dinner. Unfortunately for you, the side of Molly's plate that you were on was neighbored by Billy, who licked his lips. He then began to reach for...
15121211111111112111111.title: Molly's Family

choices: The rest of dinner is uneventful
151212111111111121111111.content:
Billy reached towards the ketchup, but he did so in a manner that he had his elbow near you, and he knocked you over. "Oops! Sorry!"

You hear a growl reverberate through the table. You look up at Molly, and saw her glaring at Billy, with her teeth bared at him, the growl coming from her throat. It was like she was saying, "Don't you dare touch him!"

Billy looked at her and whimpered, as if saying, "But I apologized to him."

You then hear a deep growl. You look and see it's coming from Mr. Sixclaw. He seemed to be saying, "Not at the table."

As for Mrs. Sixclaw, she was staring at Billy in a way that just chilled you to your very core.

"I said that I was sorry," Billy said as he brought the ketchup over to his plate. He then drowned both his burger, and the fried humans on his plate, in such a manner that you were glad that they were already dead. There was more than enough ketchup on his plate to fill twenty Olympic swimming pools.

"Billy, you know better than to waste ketchup," Molly said as she took the bottle from him. She then put a dot on her plate. "Let me help you get some ketchup." She picked you up, and placed you on her plate, near the dot of ketchup. It was the size of a normal dinner plate. You carefully use your fingered to spoon some of it onto the plate you'd been given. You then looked at the fried human on her plate; there was at least twenty of them, and they did indeed resemble french fries. You then look at the burger; you couldn't make out anything identifiable as human, but there had to be more than thirty humans in it.

"What do you make your burgers with?" you ask. "Besides humans."

"Oh I tend to mix it with cattle, pig, and even some deer," said Mrs. Sixclaw. "Others like to add other animals to their ground meat, including gazelle, crocodile, or alligator, walrus, whale, kangaroo, and some others."

"Alright," you said.

Mrs. Sixclaw smiled, and carefully placed a sliver of beef on your plate, one that resembled more like a steak than a burger. "Enjoy."

"Thanks," you said as Molly picked you back up, and placed you next to her plate, on the side away from Billy.
151212111111111121111111.title: Billy Troubles

1512121111111111211111111.content:
Thankfully, the rest of dinner was uneventful, though you were somewhat distracted whenever you heard the crunch of bone when one of the wolves ate a fried human. Thankfully, Molly and Mrs. Sixclaw chewed with their mouths close, though Mr. Sixclaw's manners could have been better; he'd chew with his mouth open, and pieces would fall on the upper part of his chin, which he'd then lick up. Thankfully, there wasn't the malice that Billy had; you could just feel him staring at you, and when you did look at him, he'd see you, and he'd take one of the fried humans, and impale them on one of his teeth, before chewing them up.

After dinner though, Molly took you back to her room. "I'm sorry about Billy's manners," she said. "Normally he's easier to deal with."

"So, what is his issue?" you ask.

Molly chuckled. "He's yet to have a sliver he couldn't pull out on his own."

"What?"

"Aesop's Fable- The Lion and The Mouse," Molly said. "Or was that the story of the slave Androcles? Either way, a powerful lion is put into a painful situation, and only a creature weaker than him is able to help him out of it."

"I've heard of them," you said as she set you on her desk. "Always thought that they were interesting."

"Yes, I enjoy them myself," Molly said with a smile. "However, Billy hasn't exactly been in a situation where he'd needed some real help from anyone else; thinks he can just do things by himself."

"And you have?" you asked.

Molly gave a nervous chuckle. "Let's just say I need help with things."

"Like what?"

"Well....
1512121111111111211111111.title: The Lion and the Mouse

15121211111111112111111111.content:
"I'm dyslexic," Molly said.

"You're dyslexic?"

Molly nodded.

"But, you were on the computer, and ordered those books," you said. "Obviously, you can read and write."

"You mean working with type," Molly said. "I don't have a problem with typed words or typing them out myself. But actually writing with ink, or reading handwritten things, they just seem look backwards to me at times."

"I take it that someone's helping you."

Molly smiled. "I've got a very good tutor."

"Who?" you ask.

Molly chuckled and said...
15121211111111112111111111.title: I'm Dyslexic."

choices: "No, but we are observing a Holy Season were one must only eat a little."
"Yes, and it's something of a long, and bad, one."
151212111111111121111111111.content:
"Lilly's been helping me out."

"Lilly?"

Molly nodded. "She's very patient, and has been helping me differentiate between my sqees and my scaws, and my plas and my blas."

"Your what?"

"Those are letters in the Wolven alphabet, much like p's and q's and b's and d's," said Molly. "Depending on how you make the shape, you'll end up with one of the four letters, or another."

"Okay," you said. "Um, will I have to learn your alphabet?"

Molly chuckled. "It would help if you did, but a Scapen doesn't need to learn it."

"Scapen?"

"It's our term for humans who come from another universe," Molly said. "It means One from Another World. During the Old Days, back when humans were seen primarily as Food and Pets, certain Scapens were worth a lot depending on the world they came from, like a hundred thousand times their weight in gold, if not more, especially if their genes were of good quality, and they knew how to make some sort of artwork."

You chuckle nervously at this. "I hope that system's been abolished."

Molly smiled. "It's been over a thousand years since that practice largely fell into disuse, though certain traces of it still exist."

"Such as?"

"Such as if you were to take a Gonan, like Lilly, as a wife."

"Gonan?"

"It's our word for humans who were born here," Moly said. "Certain Gonans were worth as much as Scapens, depending on their own genetics and abilities. We tended to want the best stock possible, both in terms of food, and as pets. As it is, one still wants Tenants with good genes, and taste good, along with ones with certain skills."

"Why?" you ask.

"They make the house worth more money," Molly said. "Those with electronic and plumbing skills lower upkeep, and having a good number of them means that one doesn't need to buy much food, especially during the drought years."

"Why would that be important?" you ask.

"While humans, and animals on your size level, are an important staple to our diet, normally we eat animals that are more on our scale," Molly said. "We also like to eat big meals, at least a fifth of our weight over the course of a day at any rate, if not more. As for the fifty humans thing, that meets our minimal dietary requirements for living."

"You're serious about that?" you ask.

Molly nodded. "A bad drought can be rough on our crops; thankfully yours require much less water, so providing that you eat the right things, a wolf like me doesn't need to resort to too many vitamin supplemental."

You then recall both the earlier "picnic" meal, and supper. From what you'd seen, maybe four hundred humans had been eaten by the wolves so far, though it could of been six if that same rate was used for breakfast. You look at Molly and ask, "Is a drought going on?"

Molly replied...
151212111111111121111111111.title: Old History and Diets

1512121111111111211111111111.content:
"Currently we're celebrating Chibune," Molly said. "It's sort of like Ramadan or Yom Kippur; in which one must fast, or at the very least, eat a fairly small amount."

"You mean, there's some sort of Holy Season thing going on?" you asked.

"Well, not quite," Molly said. "However, we are paying tribute to those who survived some of our greatest droughts, ones that threatened to bring our entire people to its knees."

"Seriously?"

"They happened roughly a thousand years ago," Molly said. "For three years, drought had lasted, and during that time, plants withered and dried up, livestock also became thin and scrawny, at least those on my size scale. Those on your scale though were relatively unaffected, as even back in Antiquity, one of the important jobs was making sure that crops and animals your size were taken care of. Back then, your people were nothing more than snacks and pets, but while we did have the cloning technology, we tended to only eat those who caused trouble, on a regular bases anyways. Normally you were only eaten as a side dish, or a quick snack. Now, the daughter of the then Ruler had a good number of Pets, both Scapens and Gonans, and she knew how bad the drought was, and it had gotten to the point that even the wealthy were having trouble buying food. It's said that her Pets had written the suggestion that she could eat them, and many had volunteered to be her meals. Now, the memory technology had been invented, so it wasn't like they'd be reduced to Blanks, meaning that they'd come back intact, both body, mind, and soul. She he told her father, and he talked to the others on Counsel. This was soon passed, with a very significant alteration; the pets, and snacks who volunteered to be regular meals would be granted the same rights as Wolvens- including a say in government, along with other things. We were quite desperate then."

"I'm surprised that humans didn't turn down the offer, and just let your kind starve to death," you said. "Or your kind just resorting to just scooping us up and eating us."

"Even then there were certain rules that kept us from just eating you, especially since you could create artwork, and improved upon it," Molly said. "I mean, even five thousand years ago, you had people making statues out of stone, depicting people from their home world, carving engravings on large flat surfaces, and then some. As for just letting us wolves starve, when a mouse can see you as a meal, just how long do you think your species would last without protection from larger predators?"

"I guess I can see how that would be an effective argument for giving humans the right to vote," you said with a chuckle.

Molly smiled. "They had plenty to gain from it. Now, the system's not perfect; there's still those who see humans as nothing more than snacks or food, or even toys, but thankfully, they comprise a fairly small number. Still, life's fine."

A while later, it was time for bed. You decide to sleep...
1512121111111111211111111111.title: Holy Season and More History

15121211111111112111111111111.content:
"Wareware wa yoru no tame ni kare o shūyō surudearou koto o naze itta no?" Lilly's father asked the moment that you came into where she lived with her parents, after traveling down a series of hallways. The man looked to be in his early twenties.

Lilly looked at her father and said, "Kare wa ue no nemuri ni wa" morī wa supea ningyō no beddo o motte imasen. Watashitachiha, gesuto-yō no beddo ga ari, sora no heya o motte imasu. Mata, watashi wa kare ga koko ni motsu nin'i no hontō no sōgo sayō o motte ita yuiitsu no ta no ningenda."

Her father sighed, and looked at you with a growl. "Watashi wa, anata ga kanojo to issho ni nete kyatchi shi, watashi wa anata no kōgan o kiriotoshimasu."

Something about his words sent a chill down your spine. "What did you guys say?"

"I reminded him that we had a guest room that had a bed," said Lilly as she escorted you down yet another hallway. "As for what he said, let's just say I'd wait a few years before asking me out on a date."

"Didn't have plans for that anyways," you said with a nervous chuckle, as you figured that there was a little more than that said.

"He has no love for Americans," Lilly said. "He lost his family in the Doolittle Raid on Tokyo."

"It wasn't very successful in my world," you said. "It didn't do much beyond scaring the Japanese a bit, and encouraging them to attack Chinese civilians."

"True, but when your wife and children are killed, you don't care if it was just the one house, or the entire city, that burned," Lilly said. "However, if you were to tell him that Japan was beating America, in any manner, he'll be happy."

"In what manner?"

"Any manner, cars, Olympics, education, anything."

You chuckle at this. "Would it help my standing if I said that I like researching the Feudal Era of Japan?"

Lilly smiled. "It would; he comes from a long line of Samurai."

"What about your mother?" you ask, as a young woman stepped out of a room.

"She's easier going, but very Traditional," Lilly said. She then looked at the woman. “Nǐ yǒu méiyǒu jī ēn de chuángshàng, māmā?”

The woman smiled and nodded. Then she looked at you, and her eyes became like ice. “Zuò rènhé shìqíng, huǐle wǒ nǚ'ér de róngyù, nǐ huì bèi zǔzhòu de làoyìn.”

"Again, don't plan on going out with me for a few years," Molly said with a nervous chuckle.

"I'm sure that both she and your father said a whole lot more than just that," you said, as she led you into your room for the night.

"They did, but you don't need to know the details."

"I'm guessing it's something along the lines of, you do anything to hurt my daughter, and you'll regret it for the rest of your life."

Lilly chuckled. "Have you heard this speech before?"

"Well, I've never really had a girlfriend, but I've seen movies," you said. "Fathers seem to threaten to shoot the boyfriend's nuts off."

Lilly smiled. "That they do."

You look at the bed, which was a traditional Japanese futon, basically a cushion with a blanket on top. "I'll see you in the morning," you said as you looked back at Lilly.

She smiled. "Same with you." She then closed the door.

You then turn the lights off, got undressed, and got under the blankets. The cushion was very comfortable, and you fell asleep almost immediately.
15121211111111112111111111111.title: In Lilly's home

choices: Lilly's the only one there, and she's cooking bacon and eggs
Lilly's Family is there having breakfast.
151212111111111121111111111111.content:
It was morning when you got up. The only way you could tell was the fact that you could smell breakfast cooking. You got out from under the covers, and went to turn on the lights. Once you did, you noticed you clothes from yesterday, with more than a few stains from when Hitler had choked you. You rub your neck as you remember the feeling. You then looked in a mirror that was in the room, and noticed something; some old pox scars were gone. You looked at other places that scars had been; they were all gone. Your body was literally a clean one, free of the various flaws it had accumulated over your life; your previous life that is. Lilly was there, busy cooking. "I hope you like bacon and eggs," she said.

"I don't mind them," you said.

"Good," she said, as she carefully set some bacon on a plate, so that the grease could soak into a paper towel.

"Um, where are your parents?" you ask.

Lilly smiled. "Breakfast."

"Breakfast?"

"They're being cooked for the Sixclaw's breakfast," Lilly said. "Though if they're being cooked as a side to sunny-side up, or scrambled eggs, or mixed into the scrambled eggs, or an omelet, that's up to the odds of them being picked by a particular wolf to be a part of that wolf's meal."

"So, you don't mind being, you know."

"Eaten?"

"Yes, eaten."

Lilly chuckled. "It can take a while for a Scapen to adjust to that little detail, that they are not at the top of the food chain anymore. A Gonan like me tends to understand; guess it helps to not have memories of a world where humans are the dominate race."

"But, have you ever been, you know?"

"Molly likes a snack every now and then," Lilly said as she placed some sunny-side ups on a plate. "Since I'm often with her, I tend to fill that role." She then set the plate on the table. "Help yourself to the bacon."

"She eats you?" you ask as you grab some bacon, and let go of it.

Lilly chuckled. "A fork might help; second drawer down is Western silverware."

"Um, thanks." You open the drawer.

"Molly does eat me," Lilly said. "Most every human gets eaten before the age of ten."

"I don't see you just letting it happen," you said. "I mean, you must struggle, at least a little."

"Yes, but Molly, and most other wolves, know how to relax a human enough to calm them down before snapping their neck."

"How?" you ask.

Lilly chuckled. "You'll find out. Now let's enjoy our breakfast before Molly comes to get you registered as residing here and takes us to school."

"School?"

"Molly needs an Adam and Eve for her Biology Class," Lilly said. "Since the guy who normally is her Adam is sick, she picked you."

"But why'd she pick me and not someone else?" you asked.

"Adams and Eves don't need to take the test on the class," said Lilly. "Everyone else does; look at it as a favor to you."

"I see."

A while later, you and Lilly finish your breakfast, put on your headsets, and go to the shelf in Molly's room. Molly then took you to a human-sized machine, one that had a hand scanner thing.

"Put your hand on the scanner," Lilly said. "It will take a sample of your DNA and register you."

"Alright," you said as you put your hand on the device. You feel a slight prick on your fingertip.

"Sample extracted," the machine said. "Verifying. Sample matches Keane ______ from, Earth PX3467831. Age: 16 Years. Ethnicity: Caucasian...." The machine listed a bunch of things about you, weight, height, right-side dominate, and so on.

"Why's that?" you ask.

"Flavor's in the genes," the woman said. "The better you taste, the more you're worth. If your offspring are also flavorful, it could be the start of a family fortune."

"I guess we'll see what the future holds," you said.

The woman chuckled. "I'll call up Molly, so that she can take you to class."

"Thanks."

The woman smiled, and led you to the ledge. She then pressed a button and said, "Molly Sixclaw to the Main Office, Human Shelf."

A minute later, Molly came to the office, and walked up the the shelf. "What classes will he be in, Mrs. Earhart?" she asked.

"With the exception of Sign Language and History, he'll be in the same as you and Rirī Lǐ lái gōngsī."

Molly smiled. "That's good to know."

Mrs. Earhart looked at you. "Whatever you do, use extreme caution out there, especially if you get into flying."

"Alright," you said as Molly picked you up.

Mrs. Earhart went back inside.

"She wouldn't happen to be the Earhart, Amelia Earhart, the one who disappeared while trying to fly around the world?"

"There are plenty of portals between the various Earths and this world," Molly said. "She came across one during her flight, just like you did."

"But, I wasn't flying," you said. "I had picked up this device that I found in my closet when I was enveloped in this light."

"Portals like to show up at any time," Molly sighed. "As far as your family will know, you either ran away, or got kidnapped, or some such thing."

You sigh at this.

Molly placed a finger by your face, the fur soaking up a tear that threatened to fall. "Let me take you to lunch, my treat."

A while later, you were eating at a restaurant, enjoying some Asian-styled food. Lilly was with you, eating with chopsticks as you ate with knife and fork. Molly though, seemed to alternate between the two, depending on what she ate. The meat she ate was humans, some living, others were dead. She used a fork when it came to the dead ones, but she always used chopsticks when it came to the living.

"It keeps them from suffering from too much fear," Lilly said; she'd noticed you watching Molly swallow some living humans.

"What?" you asked.

"The dead don't feel anything, so wolves will use forks and such with them, as well as chew them," Lilly said. "The living though, they still see with their eyes, and can feel fear, which can affect taste. Chopsticks and swallowing them whole keeps them from feeling fear, at least until after they've passed the Point of No Return."

"Still, they will, you know."

"Yes, but they will reform."

"And those who are Snacks?"

"Them too."

"But they don't bother killing them before grinding them up, or injecting them with Painkillers."

Lilly looked at you. "Some humans don't deserve to be called People. Surely you'd feel that way about Hitler."

You sighed. "You know about him?"

Lilly looked up at Molly. "She told me. He caused the death of twenty million people; those such as him deserve every bit of pain they get."

"But what about your father; he was in the Japanese Imperial Navy after all."

"He might hate Americans, and killed plenty during the war, but he didn't commit murder," said Lilly. "If he had, such as by killing POWs, he'd of ended up as a Snack."

"How would that happen?" you ask.

"Your Memories are the witnesses For you, and Against you," Lilly said. "When the Memory Chip was implanted in you, Police Officers examined them, and if they'd found out that you had done a crime, you'd of been tried by the Laws of your World. Of course, if you'd served your time already, and had stayed on the Straight and Narrow, they wouldn't make an issue of it. However, if you hadn't been punished for it, the duration of how long you'd be a Snack would depend on the Crime."

"But, couldn't that power be abused or something?" you asked. "I mean, thoughts could be controlled."

Lilly chuckled. "Your thoughts are your own; no law can be used against thoughts. You could think of Molly as a zasshuken or a gǒu, which mean mutt in Japanese and Chinese respectively, along with a few other insulting meanings, like nitwit and fool, and you wouldn't have to worry about it. Call her one though, and she might take offense at it, but I doubt she eat you for it. Of course, if someone, or something, were to attack one she cares about, well, wolves can be very bloodthirsty when it comes to taking revenge."

You then heard bones crunching above you. You look up and see Molly chewing, most likely on some deep fried humans if the breadcrumbs on her lips were an indicator.

"Remind me not to anger her," you said.

"You'll be fine around her," Lilly said. "Just as long as you don't climb up on her plate without her permission."

"I hope so," you said.

"Of course, she does enjoy snacking on her favorites, along with a few other things."

"Like what?"

Lilly smiled. "Girls have their needs."

"Something tells me not to ask further."

Lilly chuckled. "Now finish up, we'll have to go back to class soon."
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.title: During Lunch

1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.content:
The rest of school was much the same as your old one, though there were certain differences, like the one math problem you had; "If it takes one Sqink unit of energy to clone one human, state the amount of energy it would take to clone five thousand pairs, in Zank units." Thankfully, Lilly had given you an important tip; one Zank unit was the same as one thousand Sqink units. Thankfully though, the Final Bell eventually rang.


Once again, you were in the Transportation container, and again you heard the conversations, including the arguing of which Wolven band was better.

"Where were they at?" you asked, as you turned to Lilly.

"They were at their classes, just like we were," Lilly said. "Of course, since us humans outnumber the wolves by about two thousand to one, if not more, its often easier to sort us out by what family we live with. In fact, the Wolven's Family name is often added at the end of most, especially those who can't recall the family ancestor they were descended of."

"Sounds like what happened with the African slaves in the United States."

"So I've heard. In any case, they took their classes, just like we did," Lilly said. "For the most part, they had different, or human, teachers.or took the class at a later time. Of course, if they have the same class as us, they watch through a monitor, along with other families' humans, and they in turn are watched through a monitor. In fact, some of these others take the same Biology class we do."

"Please tell me they didn't watch our dissection."

Lilly chuckled. "No, they saw Mr. Simmins and Mrs. Summers being dissected. Mrs. Blackfur was the only one to see our dissections, besides ourselves and Molly, and that was to make sure that she was following directions."

"I guess that's good," you sighed with relief.

"Of course, you'd best remember what Molly did to me, and what she did," Lilly said.

"Why?"

"Because you'll have to dissect me in a few days."

You gulped. "I don't think I could handle cutting into you, and getting your blood on me."

Lilly chuckled. "I'll be drained of blood before you cut into my body." She then grinned. "Of course, you could dissect your own body, if that would make things easier on you."

"You're serious?"

Lilly nodded.

"Have you done that before?"

"Of course, even I have to know the female body, and be used to such things, as both me and Molly wish to be doctors."

"Why?"

"Because it's a very respectable, and well paying, job."

"But that would be expensive to pay for," you said.

Lilly chuckled. "It might be difficult for Molly, but for me, it will be fairly easy."

"Why?"

"Because on the Taste Scale, I rank a 8.5 out of ten, and the higher your rank, the more you're worth when you're served as part of a meal."

"You mean, you're going to be a Meal, to people whom you don't even know?"

"It's how many humans pay for collage," Lilly said. "As it is, I wouldn't be surprised if you got yourself a 9.0 rank."

"What are you talking about?"

"I saw what Earth you came from, and I know its Reputation; it's a good one."

You chuckle nervously at this. "It's not the sort I'd like to have."

Lilly chuckled as she shook her head. "You'll get used to how things work."

Eventually, Molly had it home, and let you, and the others out. As the rest when into the human-sized mouse holes, Lilly took you over to Molly, who then took the two of you to her room. Next thing you knew, you were busy with homework, thankfully Molly and Lilly were able to help you out with certain terms.

After a couple of hours of working on it, it was time for supper. You decide to eat with....
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.title: After School

choices: Aside from minor issues, dinner is, uneventful
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.content:
"You'll enjoy dinner at my place," Lilly said as she practically dragged you through the passageways.

"Slow down," you said, as you try to memorize the various turns and passages she took, and noticing all the other who seemed to turn away from the sight, and laugh. "How am I to know where we are going if I don't know where I'm going?"

Lilly chuckled. "I'll give you the nickle tour during the weekend. Until then, stay by me, or someone that Molly trusts." Then she did something you never expected; she pulled you into a corner, and kissed you, right on the lips.

"Isn't this a little sudden?" you ask. "We've barely known each other for a day."

Lilly grinned. "Little sudden would have been me kissing you the first moment I met you. Of course, I'm no fool; I'll wait until we're older before having sex with you."

"Sex with me?"

"Don't need to have a wolf's nose to know that you found me attractive."

"I'll admit to that, but still, shouldn't we start out as friends first, before going onto the next step?"

Lilly chuckled. "I've got no problems with taking it slow, boyfriend."

You chuckle nervously at this.

"What?" she asked. "You are a boy, right?"

"Yes."

"And you are my friend?"

"Yes but-"

Lilly kissed you again. "Then that makes you a boyfriend, not a boyfriend."

"So, you just see me as a friend who happens to be a boy?"

Lilly chuckled. "For now, but like I said, I wouldn't mind having your children; I have plans for making my family the main ingredient in a high class restaurant."

"Wouldn't that take a while?" you ask.

"A hundred years, if not longer," said Lilly. "Of course, if I select my potential mates accordingly, along with those of my children, and theirs, I should have well over a hundred blood relations by then."

"You do realize that you'd be at least a hundred by then."

Lilly chuckled. "Yes, but I'd look twenty, or thirty at the most. About the only annoyance would be that I couldn't be eaten while I was pregnant, but I could get eaten afterwards."

"You're serious about your plan?"

Lilly smiled. "Of course; being a doctor would be good for a career, but I need something for my daily bread until then." She then started walking down the passages again. "Coming?"

"Might as well," you said, following her. "So, just how long can a human live, with all of the cloning and whatnot?"

"Two, three, four, five thousand years, it's anyone's guess," Lilly said. "I mean, there are those who aren't eaten, and die about fifty or so years later, when their body was seventy or so years old, but that person could be over two hundred years old. It happens often enough, the whole cycle of cloning to a youthful age, while your Wolven friends grow older, and die, can affect you enough to sign a DNC form."

"DNC?"

"Do Not Clone; the next time you die, it would be for keeps, instead of getting a new body."

"I guess that's understandable."

"As for how long a human can be cloned, well, there are those from the Really Old Days, back when Memory Cloning came around, roughly three thousand years ago. Then there's the DNA on file from those before then, at least ten thousand years old."

"What do you mean?"

"Your DNA stays in the system, even if you've signed a DNC," Lilly said.

"What do they do with it?"

"Make Blanks with it, see how compatible it is with existing stock, and try to set up potential Mates for you. Also, they'll see about creating your children, and improve your bloodlines."

"What where those last two?"

Lilly chuckled. "Let's just say that if you've yet to have a child by your thirtieth birthday, the System will look for a possible mate that is of a similar age, take your DNA, as well as theirs, and essentially, create the best offspring possible. Next thing you know, you get a message that says 'Congratulations' along with the basic information about the child, who the other is, and if you wish to pick up the child or not."

"And the improvement part?"

"Similar process, though it's a little wider in range, in that it doesn't concentrate on a single wolfen home; but rather the whole world, and try to arrange possible future mates for your family members- Already got a possible match with this human in Zumania. Nice guy from his letters, but I'll try someone closer than the other side of the planet."

"Someone like me, I take?"

Lilly chuckled. "Wouldn't you prefer someone you knew as a first love?"

You smile. "I guess I would."

"Of course, if you don't pick me, there's plenty others, for both of us." She then stopped before a slightly familiar door. "I promise you, my parents will learn to accept you, it just might take my father a while longer than my mother, at least she didn't lose family to Americans during the War, unlike father."

"I just hope it's easier than last night."

Lilly smiled, and opened the door.
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.title: Heading to Lilly's Family and Children

choices: "We'll be spending the night on Molly's desk."
"We'll be spending the night in our rooms."
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.content:
Some time later, you were sitting at the table with Lilly's family. Her mother was eating her rice, with an eye on you. Her father though, just glared at you. He then stuck his chopsticks in his rice bowl, having them stand straight up, as he picked up a spoon and began having some soup. Something about the gesture made you nervous.

"Chichi wa, sore wa hijō ni shitsureida," said Lilly.

"Kare ga dono yōna chii hashi wa massugu ine shudan de shitte irudarou yō ni," her father muttered.

"Sore wa, kare ga, sore ga byōki no ishi o imi suru koto ni kidzuite inai wakede wa arimasen," Lilly said. "Osoraku watashi wa, anata wa kare ga shinu shitai koto o kare ni tsutaerubekideshou ka?"

"Qīn'ài de, tā zhǐshì yīgè niánqīng rén," said Lilly's mother. "Tā shènzhì méiyǒu chūshēng shí fāshēng de zhànzhēng." She then looked at you. "You'll have to forgive him." Her accent was somewhat thick. "Sometimes wounds don't heal, especially ones of the heart."

"I heard about what happened," you said.

"Watashi wa tsuma to musuko o ushinatta," Lilly's father muttered.

"Mori, it's been over sixty years; you need to learn to let your anger go."

"Tao, one just can't set aside that type of anger," Mori muttered. His own accent was thick, and heavy.

"But you get along fine with Mr. Jones," said Tao. "And he was in the War."

"There's a difference," muttered Mori. "He's British, not American."

"In either case, get your chopsticks out of the rice, and place them on their proper rest," Tao said. "You insult your parents when you stand them in rice like that."

Mori muttered as he removed the chopsticks and set them on a small strip of metal. He then turned it so that the points aimed at you.

"Nǐ biǎoxiàn dé bùrú tā dài láile hánguó nánhái zài zhèlǐ de shíjiān," Tao said.

"Sukunakutomo, kare ga Ajiadatta," Mori muttered.

Lilly gave you a look, one that showed that she was annoyed as well. "Always trouble when I bring someone over."

"Tends to happen with most," you said as you scoop up some rice with your fork. "I'm just glad that your mother got me utensils that I can use, instead of chopsticks."

Tao chuckled. "You Westerners always have trouble with kuàizi, so I make sure that I have the type of silverware that those of American and European origins tend to use, in addition to good guest kuàizi."

"Thank you for that."

Tao smiled. She then looked at Lilly. "So, are you and your friend spending the night here, or on Molly's desk."

"Molly's desk?" you ask.

Tao chuckled. "Even láng like a good midnight snack on occasion, as well as someone to help them out with other needs."

"Other needs?"

"Remember what happened during class today?" Lilly asked.

You blush as you remember.

"Wolves like that to, and they like a little help with it."

"You seriously don't mean that Molly will want someone to-"

"She likes a little petting in that area," said Lilly. "As do other wolves." She then looked at her mother and said...
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.title: Dinner with Lilly's family

choices: You get a solid night's rest
You're woken in the middle of the night.
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.content:
"We'll spend the night on Molly's desk."

Tao smiled. "That's good to know, just make sure that she licks you off before school; don't want you to have any yuèjīng yè on you during the day."

"What?" you ask.

"It's the same thing as jīngyè to a man."

"What?"

Lilly nudged you. "Semen and menstrual fluids." She looked at her mother. "She'll probably let us take a bath with her when we get up." She looked at you. "And he'll get to see me naked again."

You blush at the thought.

Tao chuckled. "Just don't be in a rush to turn me into a grandmother with your children; your four half siblings of my blood have already granted me twenty, especially with that half-African brother of yours running around a half dozen at any given time. Then there's your other half siblings; those three have granted your father twelve grandchildren." She looked at Mori. "Of course it would be nice to see them more often, but this old samurai is more stubborn than myself, and I consider myself to be very stubborn."

Mori glanced at her. "Futatabi sore o genkyū shi, watashi wa betsu no josei no tame ni anata o nokoshite okimasu."

Tao shoved him. "You're too stubborn to leave me."

Mori then looked at you. "Keep your hands off of my daughter, American, or I'll cut them off, along with your penis, and testicles." He then got up, and went into another room. His words caused you to shiver.

"Ruder than normal," Tao said. She then looked back at you. "I apologize for him; his first son's birthday would have been today."

"Hard to believe that he could be the father of someone as friendly as your daughter."

"Would have been easier on him if you'd been German, or Italian, or something else," Tao said. "Japan's defeat didn't bother him as much as his son's death. I'm just glad he was in the Navy, and not in the Army, and didn't have a chance to inflict 'revenge' upon prisoners. Otherwise, he wouldn't be with me."

"And you?"

"I know that this isn't China, and that land was going through some great changes at the time I came here," she said. "My children were born here, ever last one of them. While there are things that I don't care for, at least things are stable; China didn't have that. I might not like to kowtow to the láng, and be part of their meal once a week, but they are good people. My children however, are part of this world; they'll understand it better than I'll ever hope to, even if I were to live a thousand years."

"Mother, you know more than I do."

Tao chuckled at her daughter. "When I came here, I stumbled, bumbled, and fumbled my way all over this house, as an American would say. You, and your siblings, hit the ground running down the halls, never missing a turn. You even have plans to own a whole restaurant chain, with your offspring being an important part of the dishes; I doubt I'd have the courage to be fried up every day."

Lilly smiled. "I understand, mother."

Tao then looked at you. "As for you young man, you do anything to her before she's ready, Mori's threat to cut you hands and reproductive organs off will be like a slap to the face compared to what I'll do to you; removing each one of your bones, one at a time."

You chuckle nervously. "I have no intentions of doing anything she doesn't want me to do."

Tao smiled. "Good."

A while later, you and Lilly were on Molly's desk, along with some others about your age. Thing was, you were all naked, male and female alike.

I don't think I'll ever get used to this, you think to yourself.

Molly then brought over a bunch of beds, which had blankets on them. She was in a set of pajamas.

She made some motions with her hands and fingers, and you watched as the others did the same. "What does that mean?" you ask Lilly.

"It means 'Good night until later'," she answered.

Molly smiled, went to her bed, and got under the covers. She then watched as you and the other got into your beds, turning out the lights once you were under the covers.

Oh no, you thought, as you began to crawl around. Tell me she didn't slip me there.

There was a giggle, one you knew. "Lilly?"

You see some fur move, and the young woman poked her head through. "I guess Molly wanted two people to give her a good rubbing." She propped her chin on her arm, giving you a good view of her chest.

You look away. "Um, where'd she place us?"

Lilly chuckled and said...
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.title: Lilly

choices: Taking a bath with Lilly, and Molly
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.content:
"She only placed us between her breasts," Lilly said with a chuckle. "We felt that you weren't ready for a trip to her panties."

You chuckle nervously at this. "I'm glad we aren't there then."

She crawled up to you. "Why?"

"Um, because I'm a guy, and she's a girl?"

Lilly chuckled. "It's not like anything would happen; humans can't get wolves pregnant."

"But um, you and me are, um.."

"Keane, I'm naked, not foolish," said Lilly. "I'm not the sort of girl who hops into a guy's bed when she's out of her parents' eyesight for a quickie. I plan on biding my time, find the right guy, and then I might marry the guy; I want a serious relationship."

"I guess that's a good thing," you said.

"Good, now give Molly a good rubbing." She patted a certain spot. "She really likes it when people do it right here."

A while later, it was time for you to take a bath. You found yourself....
1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.title: "Between her breasts."

1512121111111111211111111111111111111111.content:
You found yourself in something the size of a pond, one that gave Molly plenty of room to lay in, under the water. You look down; the water had to be sixty feet deep, thankfully, you were wearing something akin to a life jacket. You could clearly see Molly's fur, as it moved with the water.

You turned yourself on your chest, and began swimming towards the parts of Molly that her above the water, namely her breasts. A you grabbed her fur, you quickly climbed up and sat next to Lilly, who was also wearing a similar device. She gave you a quick kiss on the cheek. "Not a bad impression of a mermaid."

You blushed at this; a three-legged cat could have swam better. You then looked, and noticed that Molly was looking at you, with a wide grin. You felt a rumble under you; she was laughing at your predicament.

Lilly chuckled, and practically jumped off of Molly's breast into the water, which was a comfortable temperature, not too warm, but not too cold. The way she swam reminded you of some Olympic swimmers you'd seen on T.V. She swam up next to the breast again, and Molly picked both her, and you, up and set you on the edge, in a depression that was the size of a family hot tub. Molly placed what had to be a handful of water to her in it, so that you and Lilly could finish bathing. Molly then grabbed a bottle, and squirted some of it into her bath water.

"Zenum Lomi," Lilly said. "Or Flea Soap as one would say in English. You don't want to bathe in that."

"Why?" you asked.

"It would burn your groin," she said. "Not seriously, but you wouldn't want to have anything by it." She then grabbed a bar of the stuff you were familiar with. "Scrub yourself good."

A while later, you and Lilly were drying yourselves off when someone came out onto the shelf.
